summary: In Steven Spielberg's massive blockbuster, paleontologists Alan Grant (Sam Neill) and Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern) and mathematician Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum) are among a select group chosen to tour an island theme park populated by dinosaurs created from prehistoric DNA. While the park's mastermind, billionaire John Hammond (Richard Attenborough), assures everyone that the facility is safe, they find out otherwise when various ferocious predators break free and go on the hunt.

"Jurassic Park" is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves all the praise it receives. The film brilliantly combines science-fiction and adventure to create a thrilling and immersive experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The visual effects are stunning and still hold up to this day, creating a believable and awe-inspiring world of prehistoric creatures brought back to life.

The cast is also top-notch, with memorable performances from Sam Neill, Laura Dern, and Jeff Goldblum. Their characters are fleshed out and believable, providing a grounded perspective on the fantastical events unfolding around them.

The film's score by John Williams is also iconic, adding an extra layer of tension and excitement to the already intense action sequences.

Overall, "Jurassic Park" is a classic that has stood the test of time and will continue to be a beloved favorite for generations to come.
Sentient dino nuggies

Although the movie did not exactly capture Crichtons vision of the story, Jurassic Park is still a five star masterpiece that no matter if you just read the book and spotted out the many, and when I mean many, I mean many, imperfections, this is still my favorite movie of all time. The acting is great, the story flows perfectly. And in some ways, you can say that the movie is better than the book. For example, why is a quarter of a 445 paged book not on the island? And why does it not get to some action until about page 200? But the book is still a masterpiece, when you put them back to back, the book is an obvious win, destroying the movie. But that is besides the point. Jurassic Park is amazing, well done, incredible performances done by Richard Attenborough, Sam Niell, Jeff Goldblum, and pretty much everybody else in this film. (Except for Ariana Richards and Joseph Mazzello, but, hey, they were just kids.)

With groundbreaking special effects, believable characters and and memorable writing, Jurassic Park roars with sheer greatness.

Rating: 99%

Jurassic Park is an exceptional movie that I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys thrilling adventures with a touch of science fiction. Directed by Steven Spielberg and released in 1993, this film is a masterpiece that has stood the test of time and continues to captivate audiences today.

One of the standout features of Jurassic Park is its groundbreaking special effects. At the time of its release, the lifelike dinosaurs depicted in the film were truly revolutionary and still hold up even by today's standards. The attention to detail in their movements and appearances is truly impressive and adds a level of realism that draws the viewer into the story.

Speaking of the story, Jurassic Park is a well-crafted tale that combines scientific exploration with thrilling action. The plot follows a group of characters who visit a theme park filled with genetically engineered dinosaurs. As they explore the park, they soon discover that things have gone horribly wrong, and they must fight to survive against the dangerous creatures that roam free.

The acting in Jurassic Park is also top-notch, with talented actors such as Sam Neill, Laura Dern, and Jeff Goldblum bringing their characters to life with depth and authenticity. Their performances help to ground the film in reality and make the perilous situations they face all the more intense.

Overall, Jurassic Park is a true classic that deserves all the praise it has received over the years. It's a thrilling adventure that will keep you on the edge of your seat, and its groundbreaking special effects and well-crafted story make it a must-see for anyone who loves movies.

With great direction, beautiful music by John Williams, and fantastic special effects that still hold up today, Steven Spielberg's Jurassic Park is a fantastic movie that you'll never get bored of with every watch.

Jurassic Park ist ein Science-Fiction- und Abenteuerfilm von Steven Spielberg. Die Handlung beruht auf dem Roman Jurassic Park von Michael Crichton, der zusammen mit David Koepp auch das Drehbuch schrieb. Es macht mir immer einen mords Spass diesen Klassiker zu sehen. 1993 schrieb Jurassic Park neue Maßstäbe im Bereich der Spezialeffekte und Computertechnik… Dieser Science-Fiction-Action-Abenteuerfilme ist einer der meinen persönlichen Lieblings Abenteuer-Dinosaurier- Filme… Ein ausgezeichnetes Drehbuch und Inszenierung mit einer großartigen Besetzung mit Sam Neill, Laura Dern, Jeff Goldblum, Richard Attenborough, Samuel L. Jackson, Wayne Knight, Joseph Mazzello und Ariana Richards… Ein Meisterwerk von Steven Spielberg.

An All Time Classic. The acting is very good all around with Richard Attenborough and Dern being the highlights. The Kids are Real Good also with lots of charm. The cinematography is phenomenal with memorable and creative sets, dinosaur designs and special effects that are still some of the best ever put to screen. The CGI & Animatronic/Practical Effects weave seamlessly to the point a lot of times you can't even tell which is which. The music is incredible with an all time classic theme song and fitting numbers to go along with this amazing adventure. This is a perfectly paced film also that builds tension perfectly. The only slight weakness is the editing is solid but not up to par with the other elements. Sometimes it jumps around a bit and relies on lots of coincidences rather than a natural flow of things. Also the villain isn't that good to boot. But everything else is just so well done and so creative that it's not a problem to suspend some disbelief with this story and logic. Great underlying message about Life and Evolution as well. Everyone should give this a watch. It's just as good as it was when it came out.

This film is a part of my life. I watched it at 12 and liked the dinosaur action, but now, watching at 14, I can safely say this is one of the best films I've ever seen, even if the novel that the film is a little bit better at the suspense and horror parts of the story. Overall, a truly fantastic film that will always win me over.

Jurassic Park – Uma Joia que não Envelhece
Jurassic Park é um filme de ficção científica e ação de 1993, dirigido por Steven Spielberg e estrelado por Laura Dern, Sam Neil, Jeff Goldblum e Richard Attenborough, entre outros, com roteiro de Michael Crichton e David Koepp. Em resumo, o filme trata sobre a construção de um parque temático onde dinossauros ressuscitados por meio de clonagem são a atração principal. O dono, John Hammond (Richard Attenborough), ao sofrer problemas com os investidores e pressionado pelo advogado Gennaro (Martin Ferrero), chama para a ilha onde foi construída a atração, três cientistas com a função de verificar a segurança, e aproveita para levar seus netos juntos no passeio inaugural. Tudo cai por terra quando o funcionário Dennis Nedry (Wayne Knight) trai seu chefe, roubando alguns embriões e desligando a segurança do parque, deixando os dinossauros à solta.
O filme é baseado em um livro homônimo, escrito por Michael Crichton, do qual eu não li e, portanto, não poderei discutir sob o ponto de vista de adaptação, o que planejo corrigir futuramente. Mas, como obra isolada, Jurassic Park é praticamente uma obra prima, tanto do ponto de vista técnico como de roteiro. 
Sobre a história, ela é bem estruturada, com nenhum grande furo que eu pudesse identificar, e diálogos naturais e bem escritos em sua maioria, com algumas exceções, em especial se tratando das crianças. A atuação, infelizmente, deixa à desejar. Apesar de não ser ruim, a qualidade dos diálogos não reflete na expressão dos personagens, que por vezes parecem ser um tanto quanto robotizados e metódicos ao extremo, com exceção de Jeff Goldblum, que interpreta o personagem Ian Malcom, um matemático que visita a ilha como representante do advogado, e atua magistralmente como tal.
Os momentos de tensão e ação, que são muitos depois que começam, são todos fenomenais e conseguem prender a atenção do espectador, além de o manter tenso a todos os momentos. Apesar de ser, de fato, um filme repleto de cenas e momentos de ação, o ritmo da obra é agradável desde o início, mais parado, mas não por isso lento. Você fica engajado na história e quer continuar assistindo para descobrir o que acontecerá nos próximos minutos.
A parte técnica do filme consegue ser melhor ainda, entregando exatamente o que promete, com efeitos extremamente modernos para o início da década de 90 e ao que ao mesmo tempo não ficaram datados. A mistura de efeitos práticos e digitais os tornam ainda recentes nos dias de hoje, e mesmo com a diferença dos animatrônicos para os dinossauros gerados digitalmente, não causa estranhesa enquanto você assiste, com transições quase imperceptíveis entre os dois métodos. O áudio em um geral também está impecável, tanto nos sons emitidos pelos dinos quanto na música, uma composição perfeita pelo maestro John Williams. Não poderia se dizer que o filme seria o mesmo sem a trilha sonora cuidadosamente selecionada para os momentos certos, e que ainda continua sendo linda de se ouvir fora dele.
E antes de terminar, gostaria de elogiar a parte científica do filme. Apesar de não ser totalmente precisa, ainda assim é uma obra que tenta cuidar para ser o mais verossímil possível e passar a sensação de que aquilo pode muito bem ter acontecido no nosso mundo. As conversas do Doutor Grant (Sam Neil) tentam sempre passar um teor científico, com informações que na época eram sim verdadeiras, apesar de já terem sido desclassificadas há muito. Porém, um dos erros que mais me incomoda e foi deixado por causa do livro, que também continha esse erro, é o dos velociraptores, que na verdade seriam, pela aparência e descrição de hábitos, Utahraptors. Além disso, a falta de penas em algumas espécies é triste, porém compreensível do ponto de vista cinematográfico.
Concluindo, Jurassic Park é um filme incrível, com alguns defeitos, mas que são esquecíveis perto de suas qualidades, uma joia que estava à frente do seu tempo e continua sendo fruto de estudo para os atuais nomes do cinema

When it comes to being to the most iconic film of all time next to Star Wars, Alien and Back to the Future, this movie is certainly on the list of being an infamous classic. Even up till now this movie is one of the best movies to watch even with the newer movies of today and it's exception visuals. 

This is of the best movies that there is about dinosaurs, you might say Jurassic world but it's not like this one, and even though I always to see how Jurassic park would have been if it was open before Jurassic world came out, it can't compare to this movie. I have always wanted a classic Jurassic park shirt, I have never gotten one. What makes the visuals so great is that at the time this movie came out, it was practical effects vs special effects, animatronics vs CGI, that's why they did their best to show how good each one is. Some scenes that I thought was an animatronic was actually special effects. There is so many scene that is jaw dropping amazing like the sick Triceratops, the T-Rex escaping and even the venomous Dilophosaurus, even everything else like the cars, the park itself and even the atmosphere itself like the forests and the storms. Everything is done to perfection. The sound is one of the best ever, it's extremely loud and the bass is very heavy feeling like you at the theatre, especially with that T-Rex roar. With its amazing sound and visuals it makes you feel like you're really there making the dinosaur scenes even more intense even though it's not a horror movie. I don't think I could say anymore about how great this movie is.

An excellent film,  one of the few I would say is even better than the book! The Crichton book was different in fundamental ways, for example both Ian (the scientist) and the grandpa figure John Hammond die in the book.  Crichton also wrote Westworld and they are in some ways almost the same story, about a theme park's characters gone awry. Probably one of the more amazing things about Jurassic Park was the state of the script almost up to the point where they started filming. The script was drastically different and underwent some incredible late revisions... to understand how different this movie could have been, the very first script draft included things like Alan Grant leaning down and licking the dinosaur bone he was excavating.... scenes that were thankfully removed.  This movie version took the best parts of the book without dumbing it down.  Really sold the idea, turning a wonderful novel into a great family movie with provocative, intelligent themes.

I personally really like Steven Spielberg, and I like his films, especially Schindlers List, Jaws and ET:The Extra Terrestrial. While a tad too long and has one or two loose ends in the plot, Jurassic Park nevertheless has thrilling action and has sheer evidence of the director's vision and effortless verve at work. John Williams's score is absolutely terrific, definitely one of the more memorable scores in a Steven Spielberg movie, the score for Jaws like Psycho is one of the main reason why I am so scared to go into the sea now. The acting is really not bad at all, Sam Neill and Laura Dern have given better performances but they were good. Jeff Goldblum is terrific, and as Dennis Nedry Wayne Knight is suitably more subdued. Richard Attenborough, a talented actor and a even more talented director also is good as John Hammond, while child star Joseph Mazello, who surprised me in Shadowlands is appealing as Tim. However, the real stars are the dinosaurs, especially the T-Rex, the mix of computer animation and models is inspiring. The cinematography is astounding, the script is good and the direction is lively. I haven't read Michael Crichton's book, but regardless this is a hugely enjoyable film. 9/10 Bethany Cox

Though one of the most influential and highly regarded movies of all time, Jurassic Park is far from perfect but does just enough right in terms of suspense and originality to keep a movie full of unclever dialogue and coincidences from plummeting toward extinction.

Ignore the mind-boggling number of close calls, where the protagonists manage to avoid what would seem to be certain death.  Ignore the predictability, where it becomes evident early on in the proceedings that the bad guys are doomed to be dinosaur food, the secondary characters are expendable, and the good guys are destined to outsmart those annoying velociraptors.  Stephen Spielberg's Jurassic Park, a theme park of a movie run amok, is a thrill ride from beginning to end, buoyed by a great story, some interesting characters, nice cinematography and music, and some excellent state-of-the-art, for its time, special effects.  Sure, the aforementioned shortcomings get annoying after a while, but, overall, it is plenty of fun.

This is, admittedly, a commercial summer blockbuster film fit for watching with an oversized bucket of popcorn. But the craftsmanship here is of the highest possible caliber. The characters are stereotypes but interesting, the humour is doled out in regular portions but actually merits sincere laughter, and the suspense is real and sustained. Oh, the suspense! I was truly on the edge of my seat for so much of the film. This movie manages to be both wildly, unbelievably entertaining and something more - a lot more. It's a satire on theme parks and trendy philosophers but it's also designed to appeal to theme park fans and fans of Continental Structural Philosophers. Steven Spielberg, you are a genius.
Incredibly complex, heartfelt, and believable for what it could have been. A philosophical, fun-filled adventure. Near perfect, and a blast every time!

It's not like the movie developed them enough to make you terribly concerned if they'll be eaten, all the movie did to make you care about them was to show they're humans, that's it. The graphics were pretty good though.

And sadly most of the other entries fall short of what this one achieved in at least one of those aspects.

Jurassic Park is the starting and end point for two generations of action adventure summer blockbusters. It is the dawning of believable CG effects in major motion pictures, illustrating what can be done with the burgeoning technology. It is also largely responsible for the death of animatronics. A considerably more time consuming and expensive way at special effects and far more constricting at what can be done. It is arguable that this shift was inevitable but Jurassic Park was objectively a catalyst in this transition. Fortunately for us all this catalyst is also a defining triumph in Speilbergs career. As smart as it is technically inventive and as harrowing as it is emotionally resonate. Jurassic Park is Speilbergs at the top of his game. A masterfully shot adaptation of Chricton's novel that helped shape the film world immediately and  long after it's release.

Jurassic Park is a masterpiece and one of Steven Spielbergs most iconic films. Based on the iconic book by Michael Crichton it tells the story of how a powerful rich man John Hammond played by the great late Richard Attenborough resurrects dinosaurs with genetic engineering and creating a theme park on a remote island featuring these dinosaurs.  Of course something goes wrong and the dinosaurs escape wreaking havoc and terrifying the human characters. This movie is now a classic and it has aged very well since 1993. There are many things that work here to perfection. A script that is able to create suspense as well as  a strong sense of adventure. The characters are some of the best written characters in cinematic history dominiated by the trio of Sam Neill as paleontogist Alan Grant, Laura Dern as Ellie Satler a paleobotanist and the exquisite and charismatic Jeff Goldblum as chaos theorist Ian Malcom. These actors do an incredible job of playing characters we grow to care about and we see them being transformed and evolving as the movie progresses with one of the highlights being Ian Malcoms Jeff Goldblum with his punchlines and smartly scientific delivery. However the stars are the dinosaurs who are a combination of CGI and animatronics. This movie revolutionized Hollywood since it was the first time such lifelike creatures had been brought to the screen with this kind of technology and the world has never been the same. The dinosaurs are realistic, lifelike, beautiful and completely terryfing with the highlights being the raptors and the T Rex. The incredible music of John Williams is now iconic and is recognized all over the world and Spilerbergs direction makes this a very fun movie that knows how to keep the audience in suspense. Its filled with science, moments of sheer terror, adventure, and a sense of childhlike wonder that makes this movie  a delight and the one started a new era of dinosaur movies.
An eternal classic that should be watched by all.

I personally really like Steven Spielberg, and I like his films, especially Schindlers List, Jaws and ET:The Extra Terrestrial. While a tad too long and has one or two loose ends in the plot, Jurassic Park nevertheless has thrilling action and has sheer evidence of the director's vision and effortless verve at work. John Williams's score is absolutely terrific, definitely one of the more memorable scores in a Steven Spielberg movie, the score for Jaws like Psycho is one of the main reason why I am so scared to go into the sea now. The acting is really not bad at all, Sam Neill and Laura Dern have given better performances but they were good. Jeff Goldblum is terrific, and as Dennis Nedry Wayne Knight is suitably more subdued. Richard Attenborough, a talented actor and a even more talented director also is good as John Hammond, while child star Joseph Mazello, who surprised me in Shadowlands is appealing as Tim. However, the real stars are the dinosaurs, especially the T-Rex, the mix of computer animation and models is inspiring. The cinematography is astounding, the script is good and the direction is lively. I haven't read Michael Crichton's book, but regardless this is a hugely enjoyable film. 9/10 Bethany Cox

As a kid I often used to hear people talk about Jurassic Park, but since I didn't know English and I don't like watching old movies, I didn't really feel like checking this out. It was only after I gained interest in watching movies did I decide to give this a look. I just got my Prime subscription and had seen everything, so I decided to give this a try. And boy was I surprised! I didn't even know what I was going to expect and being a huge sucker for wildlife and natural environment, this movie made me delve into a fantasy world. Undoubtedly this is an iconic movie right off the bat.
Jurassic Park has some of the most iconic characters from the 90s science fiction. The reason being that in spite of being a movie about dinosaurs, it was able to put the human characters inside with such effortlessness. I really liked John Hammond. What he did in the movie is something I'd really want to see happen in real life. Ian Malcolm also made the side characters look very interesting, as though he alone carried the burden of the comic relief scenes. And when it comes to the CGI, I don't think we even need enough words. This was fire right from the start. Seeing dinosaurs just do something on the screen and behave like actual wild animals was so awesome.
The story was also pretty good. The idea that a scientist has created a wildlife sanctuary for dinosaurs where we travel using an self driven car is a fantasy for many Millennials and Gen-Z alike. If something like that happens in real life we will definitely want to give it a look. And seeing what all misadventures they had to go through, we have the uneasy feeling watching it. The T-Rex scenes still hold very well, especially the iconic part where the children are being driven away in the car.
I really wanted Jurassic Park to be a standalone movie, which could be remastered into 4K as time and technology gets better. Even today it doesn't look outdated, other than the fact that some dinosaurs have been discovered to look different like the velociraptor, and the camera quality is very 90s-ish. But watching it on a big TV really gives the feel of seeing it in a theatre due to the old resolution. A definite recommendation from me.
A nearly perfect summer blockbuster.

Jurassic Park - 10/10. Steven Spielberg's Jurassic Park is a testament towards blockbuster filmmaking. For any director that needs inspiration on creating a great big budget film, look no further than JP. Of course at first glance people will rave about the cutting edge technology used to bring the CGI to life (to this day some scenes still hold up like they were made in present day). But more or less the movie's real core and brilliance comes from its moral compass and what it tries to talk about. Michael Crichton and David Koepp expertly talk about the ethical ramifications of bringing to life dinosaurs and the idea of just using them as show pieces. Outside of the terrifying and amazing action set pieces, that lunch table scene where the conversation touches upon playing god is by far one of the best written scenes in a blockbuster film. You got fantastic performances from Sam Neil, Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, Samuel L. Jackson, Richard Attenborough, and Wayne Knight. You have legendary music from John Williams. You got the picturesque views of Hawaii filling in for Costa Rica. And you have dinosaurs ruling the earth again! What else do you need!?

Thanks to Crichton's genius mind the world got to enter Jurassic Park. Literally a looking glass into the world of an extinct monster-sized species, and a new age of visual FX techniques that had only been touched upon by a few other ground breaking films before it. There is not a moment wasted in this film, combining adventure, wonder, comedy and horror in a perfectly balanced piece of immersive art. The pre-production itself was thoroughly planned out so there wasn't any room for Spielberg to experiment or deviate, but he held the reigns tightly and seen the picture through to it's best. Steven Spielberg (E.T. The Extra Terrestrial) has proven countless times that he's amongst the best storytellers in the film industry. With Jurassic Park, he succeeded once again delivering an unforgettable cinematic experience. Based on Michael Crichton's novel, Jurassic Park follows two paleontologists invited to an island to preview a new amusement park. Here they discover the island is full of living dinosaurs, brought to life by genetic scientists. Where Jurassic Park sets a whole new standard is the pioneering of visual and sound effects. The dinosaurs onscreen look insanely real, both CGI and animatronic. I recall being absolutely terrified as a child at the enormous roar of the T-Rex. Upon re-release in 2013, the movie looked just as breathtaking as it did 20 years ago on the big screen. Enhanced by the heartwarming score provided by John Williams (Jaws), the first encounter with the Brachiosaurus still amazes me to this day. Jurassic Park was one of the first movies I saw at the cinema and one of the first movies that began my love affair with film.

A cautionary tale of what can go wrong by skipping background checks on your employees or ignoring local weather forecasts, Jurassic Park is as much a delight as it is horrifying. Hollywood's finest magic is on display as a mix of practical effects and computer animation brings to life Universal Studios' bravest moment yet; showing a Tyrannosaurus Rex eat a lawyer off of a toilet. Steven Spielberg does Michael Crichton's novel more than justice, but he misses out on a full star here for not having the balls to kill a kid.

The Movie to define a Generation.
If you were born in the 90s or before, you had a connection with people...you absolutely loved this movie, and it made a mark on you. I think most people remember when they saw this movie first, because it was that awe inspiring of an experience. I remember that it was the first pg-13 movie I was allowed to watch, and what a way to start my grown up movie experience!!! As you hear John Williams glorious theme start to swell, and you see Alan remove his glasses and start to tremble, you know you're about to witness one of the most magical moments ever put on cinema. "Jurrassic Park" de 1993 es una película de la cual me sorprendería que alguien, amante del cine o no, nunca haya escuchado hablar de ella. Ya que es una cinta que marcó un hito en la historia fílmica por sus efectos especiales y que ha constituido una cultura popular alrededor de ella, siendo ampliamente recordada hasta estos días.
Una cinta que viene de la mano del director Steven Spielberg quien, hasta ese momento, había dirigido películas como: E.T. El Extraterrestre (1982), Tiburón (1975), la saga de Indiana Jones (1981), entre otros éxitos en taquilla. Un cineasta que tiene una forma de narrar y contar historias únicas, mágicas y capaces de meterte en la película tal como lo hace en esta historia a partir de la idea de la novela escrita por Michael Crichton.
Parque Jurásico en español es una cinta de ciencia ficción y aventuras que nos cuenta la historia de cómo el millonario, John Hammon (Richard Attenborough), ha construido un parque repleto de dinosaurios reales en una isla cerca de Costa Rica. Aunque, debido a la presión de los inversores del proyecto, Hammon tiene que buscar a un grupo de expertos para que dictaminen si el lugar es seguro o no, antes de su apertura al público.
 Por lo que el paleontólogo Alan Grant (Sam Neill), la paleobotánica Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern), el matemático Ian Malcom (Jeff Goldblum) y un representante de los inversores, Donald Gennaro (Martin Ferrero), tendrán que aventurarse en este fantástico lugar. Sin embargo, las medidas de seguridad del parque no prevén el instinto de supervivencia de la naturaleza ni la codicia del ser humano, lo cual provocara una crisis inevitable.
En lo particular, Jurassic Park es una película que recuerdo con bastante cariño, ya que en más de alguna ocasión la vi junto a mis padres por la televisión cuando era niño. Simplemente me fascinaba ver a los protagonistas interactuando con los temibles dinosaurios junto a sus sorprendentes rugidos cuando perseguían a alguna persona, ¡era increíble!
Sin embargo, recientemente que he vuelto a ver la película, puedo mencionar que mi yo de pequeño se emocionaba justamente. Esto, ya que los efectos especiales y visuales de la cinta, junto a la banda sonora de John Williams, constituyen uno de los puntos más destacables.
 Un filme que parece no haber envejecido con los años, ya que, incluso en una época en la que el CGI está a la orden del día, sigue siendo disfrutable y bastante admirable el trabajo realizado, más allá de una trama bastante floja.
Ya que, si bien gracias a la dirección y toque de Spielberg el espectador se sumerge en la cinta, no es gracias al desarrollo de la misma, sino a causa de la acción y suspenso en la que se ven envueltos los protagonistas. Una película que no se sostendría sin el espectacular Tyrannosaurus Rex quien es el que le da sentido a los hechos que suceden. Y que incluso provoca que la cinta tenga un conflicto más o menos desarrollado.
Esto en vista que los principales protagonistas solamente están a merced de los hechos y no hay espacio para desarrollar o conocer sus verdaderos conflictos personales. Por lo que algunos personajes se sienten forzados en sus acciones y en las relaciones que estos tienen entre sí.
Aunque solamente destacar aquello que tiene como protagonista a los dinosaurios sería desmerecer secuencias magnificas en las que el director muestra un tipo de terror similar al de sus primeras cintas como la de Tiburón en la que el suspenso y terror está muy bien utilizado.
Una película que es contada de forma lineal con un final abierto que dejó espacio para secuelas que se realización años después y que incluso han logrado extenderse hasta la fecha con cintas como Jurassic World. 
En todo caso este filme busca retratar la descarada ambición humana por el dinero y el control sobre la naturaleza. Así lo hace ver, a manera de metáfora, el personaje del Dr. Ian Malcolm cuando dice "Ustedes utilizan sus conocimientos como el niño que ha encontrado el revólver de su padre".
En definitiva, Jurassic Park es una película que todo amante del cine o cualquier otra persona debería de ver ya que refleja completamente el trabajo minucioso en la creación de una cinta diferente de ciencia ficción con los recursos de la época. Pero más allá de eso es una historia para disfrutar e imaginar que sería sí esta isla en verdad existiera.

The star of Jurassic Park was not the dinosaurs so much as it was that "Life will find a way".  In that sense the terror of the dinosaurs, and the awe, is a stand-in for the sheer power of life itself to find a way to survive and thrive under difficult situations.  A monster movie works best when the monsters, in this case humanities re-invented dinosaurs, represent something more powerful than that which we can control.  Often times it is the power of nature and/or humanities' efforts that create an unbalancing of nature that the monster represents.  The chaos mathematician, despite his eccentricity, is our best direct voice of wisdom and understanding of the real magic and his words point to the real star of this film.  Complex, adaptive systems is a real science that expands well-beyond the realm of chaos theory but can be seen to work in the same space.  Systems are orderly but also are stable in response to disturbance.  Life has developed over millions of years and has shown in ways deeper than we fully appreciate how as an intertwined set of complex, adaptive systems, it has survived and flourished in so many places and in spite of so many threats of mass extinction.    

The second and third film try out their own higher minded principles but these principles are merely derivative and not as well executed.  The next two sequels are held together only by their action sequences and the desire to try to escape immediate danger.  As such they are, at best, merely coda's to this first movie.  

It is the temptation to feel like one can be in control of these forces in some final way that is the crucial element, the villain so to speak, that puts the viewer into the fullest appreciation of the power that is life itself.  This element is present in the first movie , the second movie approaches it but not in any new way, and the last movie is even more derivative on that note.  In the first movie, each character's arc reflects on this theme of rational control vs creative freedom to escape control.

"Jurassic Park" is clearly one of the best examples of a film being ahead of its time!  I mean, just look at the special effects of the dinosaurs themselves!  They are so well done!  Anyway, another aspect of the film that I really loved was how it approached the theme of messing with forces that you don't understand and how those forces can quickly turn against you (in this case, the scientists trying to control the dinosaurs, despite the fact that the dinosaurs were created with "survival of the fittest" mentality).  The only issue I had with this film was that the pacing was a bit slow at places.  Overall, "Jurassic Park" is definitely worth the watch if you are a huge fan of Steven Spielberg's films and dinosaurs!

Jurassic Park is about paleontologists Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler and mathematician Ian Malcolm are among a select group chosen to tour an island theme park populated by dinosaurs created from prehistoric DNA. While the park's mastermind, billionaire John Hammond, assures everyone that the facility is safe, they find out otherwise when various ferocious predators break free and go on the hunt.

Directed by Steven Spielberg, starring Sam Niell & Laura Dern. A prehistoric classic that will never go extinct. This film needs no introduction. During quarantine I decided to go through each of the Jurassic films and take that journey to relive some of the best monster movies to come to the big screen. After watching Jurassic Park, once again I am in awe of how well the effects still hold up. This movie doesn’t feel dated at all, even 27 years later. The story of man creates monsters and monster turning on man is something that is done over and over, but Jurassic Park always holds the bar for the best that genre can offer. This film made everyone fear dinosaurs just as Spielberg made everyone scared to go back into the water with Jaws (1975).
So good to see on that big screen and surround sound!

The violence, the visual effects, the tension, the amazing concepts, the scares, the near death stress builders, the stories of survival, the iconic lines, it's all here. It's a classic for a reason. Everything about it screams "Hollywood summer blockbuster!" It's entertaining in every way and it never gets boring. However, the child acting is as always cringe worthy and sometimes they overact, but Spielberg does the best he can with giving these kids the direction they need. There is also a couple of weird moments in the film that didn't make sense to me. But the movie's pacing and entertaining visuals can easily distract you from these things and put you on a thrill ride through the one and only...  Jurassic Park.

Spielberg's skill here - as in all his best action blockbusters - is a lot to do with pacing. As in the superior Jaws he is in no rush to bring on the dinosaurs until he has delineated the characters and the setting. He elicits slyly comic characterisations from the dependably eccentric Jeff Goldblum and wonderful Wayne Knight, and gets Sam Neill and Richard Attenborough to supply the emotional tug. And of course the VFX are brilliant, seamlessly meshing with the live action and convincing you that everything faked is real. It would have benefited from a shorter running time, but it's  a hell of a lot better than his soporific sequel.

I understand that in 1993 there might not have been that many sources to use but newer movies like Jurrasic World: Fallen Kingdom could have definitely have upgraded the designs. I feel like this movie franchise has greatly affected what's true about dinosaurs. And even if there were to make a historically accurate Jurrasic park movie it definitely wouldn't be as popular since one of the main reasons people go to see these movies are too watch Giant, terrifying, scaley Trexs roar and rip people apart and a real T rex is not like that. But I definitely don't hate this movie! The animatronics used are incredible, The music always gives me chills and it has a great story! (also don't take this too seriously, I'm just an angry teen ;-)

There is no point in being either too harsh or too full of praise in evaluating this movie. It is was a huge hit when it was released in the 90s. Its primary audience is kids and teenagers. Now it seem mildly entertaining but mostly ridiculously stupid. The key component of this idiocy is making dinosaurs look and behave literally like serial killers from mediocre horror flicks. Velociraptor portrayed twice their alledged size open door knobs, being one example. I am sorry but this looks idiotic. As well as the climatic major battle between the t-rex and velociraptors. As well as a boy surviving a shock of 10,000 volts and fall from good 15 meters. On the plus side, there several funny episodes and deep philosophical monologues. Other than that the movie has nothing to offer for a contemporary viewer. It is neither too bad to deserve oblivion, neither is good enough to age gracefully like some other thriller classics with old times special effects.

I've watched this film because ever since childhood, I've always been fascinated by dinosaurs. And I wasn't wrong with this film being the best movie about dinosaurs as it was a masterpiece by Steven Spielberg! Based on Micheal Crichton novel of same title, Jurassic Park is a science fiction, adventure and thriller movie that I'm sure an achievement movie on its own and will definitely be loved by kids and adults even up to this day. I think the reason for the success of the film and its unforgettable feat were the great storyline which was partly written by the original novelist himself, great performances by the casts and great special effects, of course! Those dinosaurs that lived millions of years ago seems to be so alive and real! Another contribution to its success was the right balance of its themes of adventure, suspense, thriller, science fiction and drama. It even got a lesson to impart about containing life vs. scientific manipulation. I'm not surprised that it spawned 5 sequels over the years because of its success. And I won't be surprise if its popularity among us won't fade in time it is simply now a classic dinosaur movie.
Jurassic Park's pure kinetic cinematic experience is leveled with an undying respect for nature's kingdom.

Jurassic Park is an amazing movie and my personal favorite.  First off, the dinosaurs look awesome and feel real.  They each have unique behaviors and act as actual animals.  The reasoning to why they looked so real was because of the use of animatronics and practical effects.  CGI was used sparingly, and for the most part it still looked better than a lot of CGI today.  The second reason why Jurassic Park is such a good movie is because of the characters.  The characters and dialogue felt real.  Most, if not all of the characters are intriguing and lovable.  Hammond, played by Richard Attenborough, is sweet and full of excitement, which makes it easy to love him.  Jeff Goldblum's Ian Malcolm is my favorite character in the movie.  His personality is very likable and unique.  He is very quirky and sometimes even cocky, and is also the main source of the little humor in the movie, but yet he is also the main voice of realism.  Also, almost everything he says is quotable.  I would love to describe the other characters, but I don't want to extend this review too long, and you can just watch the movie yourself.  Finally, the music in this movie is phenomenal.  John Williams really captures the magnificence and terror in his scores.  Sorry for the long review, but I wanted to express my main thoughts on why Jurassic Park is such an extraordinary film.

Jurassic Park was a cornerstone of special effects and even today after 25 years the film is as good as it was on the day it released. Based on Michael Crichtonâ(TM)s novel the synopsis goes something like this- On a small island off the coast of Costa Rica exists a most unusual animal preserve by the name of Jurassic Park. Operated by dinosaur lover John Hammond (Richard Attenborough), Jurassic Park is the first of its kind. Its population of creatures includes brachiosaurs, dilophosaurs, tricerotops, velociraptors, and a Tyrannosaurus Rex, each of which has been cloned using the latest technology that takes DNA from dinosaur-biting prehistoric insects preserved in amber, and uses that DNA for the re-creation. When the consortium funding Jurassic Park become concerned that all is not as it should be, Hammond is forced to call in three experts: paleontologist Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neill), his partner, paleo-botanist Dr. Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern), and the brilliant-but-cynical mathematician Dr. Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum). When the trio arrives at Jurassic Park, they are astonished by what it represents. It doesn't take long, however, for astonishment to turn to horror. Great film by a great director.(Movie magic result in live breathing Dinosaurs).

"Jurassic Park" filmed by Steven Spielberg in 1993 truly set the tone for thriller movies that would later be made in the future. At a young age we were taught about these massive beasts roaming the earth, animals far beyond our greatest imaginations only to grow up and realize that these massive beasts were not to be seen again. Well Jurassic Park fulfilled those imaginations. When Steven Spielberg created this film, he opened our minds to ideas and scenarios beyond this world. He created difficult situations that were intense but weren't too intense for families and friends.
  	During the time action packed thriller movies never met in between. It was either too graphic or not graphic enough, but Spielberg found a way to change that. With C.G.I being a new form of technology the graphics on most films during that time were bland and somewhat unrealistic but in this film it was so detailed that it began to open people's minds on things that could be possible if they were to put their minds to it. At the same time this film showed a sense of humanity in a moment of terror. It reminded us that even in the darkest of times, humanism could be the deciding factor of life and death. Overall Steven Spielberg did an excellent job in sharing his imagination with the rest of the world, and by giving the rest of the world-especially children an imagination of their own. So much so that various movies have been made replicating this great movie.

Jurassic Park doesn't really need much reviewing by this point, but I saw it at the Royal Albert Hall in London recently with live orchestral accompaniment and fell in love with it all over again.

One of Spielberg's finest, Jurassic Park has all the hallmarks of the filmmaker who made Jaws and grew even more in their expertise by the time he retread ground with dinosaurs. 

Spotlights are everywhere in this masterful film full of great camera techniques, memorable characters, great visual and aural storytelling, brilliant set design, and of course...those special effects. There's a reason why I make jokes at more modern movies' special effects saying "X years after Jurassic Park". This was 1993. And it made you believe in dinosaurs. I mean, they did exist, but whatever.

In regards to the orchestra that played, it does make one realise that goddamn, they play the main theme a lot. But it's another John Williams masterpiece, so it's fine. It captures everything good about this movie. The joy, the wonder, the adventure. 

That's what every subsequent movie in the series lacks. That wonder. The miracle of dinosaurs. It's an amazing incredible thing. It's not meant to be a horror movie. Or a slasher. It just happens to turn out that way. But that's not the focus.

It's not about that. Jurassic Park is about a man who realises he's ready to start a family. That's the good shit. Not T-Rex and Raptor versus fake dinosaur fights.

Spielberg is the master. And goddamn, there will never be a more joyful reveal than the entire "Welcome to Jurassic Park" sequence.
(Star rating based on Little Man of the Santa Franciscio Chronicle)

Without a doubt, Jurassic Park (1993) is one of the most iconic science fiction movies of all-time. In my opinion; regardless of genre, it is one of the greatest films ever. It certainly deserves its place as one of Director Steven Spielberg's best works in his long and prestigious career. The original film has a magic that none of its sequels have come close to replicating. Some reasons are derived from the fact that it is the first film in the franchise. Obviously, it has the novelty of showing the audience dinosaurs for the first time. Dinosaurs had been presented as monsters in films before Jurassic Park [e.g. King Kong fighting a Tyrannosaurus Rex in King Kong (1933)]. Nonetheless, Jurassic Park took great lengths to portray dinosaurs as realistic as possible based on the knowledge of its time. Accordingly, the movie is the first time that an authentic take on dinosaurs were presented on the big screen. Moreover, the film does well to capture the awe and amazement in the reactions of its characters when they initially come face to face with gigantic sauropods. Next, the discussions of the hypothetical science and the ethics behind wielding that power is fascinating, especially since the ethical debate regarding cloning was a significant topic back in the 1990s. No other film in the series provides nearly as interesting fruit for thought. Other reasons Jurassic Park is vastly superior to its sequels are not exclusive to it being the first in the series. For instance, it has a strong cast that portrays great characters. In addition, there is great chemistry among the cast and their characters. It is an amazing group that has not been replicated by the later films. Similarly, the sequels fall short in capturing the same level of terror that exudes through the screen once the safeguards of the park fall apart. I was in the second grade when my dad brought me to see Jurassic Park. I was fascinated by dinosaurs and super excited to watch a movie featuring them. I did not realize how petrified I would be by the legendary horror scenes featuring the Tyrannosaurus Rex and Velociraptors. I was so scared during the movie that I immediately got physically sick when I returned home. In the sequels, the carnivores have become carnival theme park monsters. They chase around the heroes but they never catch them. Moreover, the feeling of danger has been completely lost. Instead, they only feast on villains or secondary and tertiary supporting characters who the audience has little connection to in the films. Finally, the music from the movie is also epic. It is not surprising since legend John Williams scores the soundtrack. When you analyze the combination of all those factors, you understand why Jurassic Park is a truly special movie. Not surprisingly, the most memorable scenes and quotes in the franchise are in the first film. As John "Ray" Arnold (Samuel L. Jackson) would say it, "Hold on to your butts."

For my full/ detailed review, please see:

An genuinely thrilling adventure with dynamic lovable characters, particularly Jeff goldblum's Ian Malcolm, Jurassic Park brings together stunning visuals, thrilling moments, a well put together story, and an absolutely fantastic score to deliver us a masterpiece 65 million years in the making
One of the most thrilling, scariest movies of my childhood -- the original Jurassic Park will always be a classic that paved the way for a highly successful franchise.

And now we've come to the big one, Jurassic Park, the highest grossing film of all time. When people got to see this years back they are in awe just like me and they were on the edge of the seat when the thrill starts. Jurassic Park is a theme park of where dinosaurs is shown in the park of where dinosaurs lived a million years ago and to entertain people and kids with awe and they got rides in the park like most theme parks got. The film takes place at Isla Nublar. Three doctors, Alan Grant, Ellie Sattler and Ian Malcolm and others are with John Hammond travelling to a wildlife park called Jurassic Park where Hammond created cloned dinosaurs on Costa Rican island. While they arrive, they saw a brachiosaurus and Grant couldn't believe his eyes when Hammond said "We have a T-Rex." The group watched a Saturday Morning Cartoon where DNA is telling you all about dinosaurs by extracting from mosquitoes. Sheesh! Looks like somebody been watching too many Looney Tunes! They went into the tour vehicles along with Hammond's grandchildren, Lex and Tim and then comes across a sick triceratops. And then the power goes off so is the tour vehicles and a nerdy lazy computer programmer, Dennis Nedry, has been bribed by Dodgson, is stealing dino DNA and the Tyrannosaurus rex appears by breaking through the electric fences. Now let me get to something which REALLY mine and everybody's minds. First I'll start off by saying that I f**king love the special effects. The special effects are the highlight of the film and it mixes a lot of it with robotic puppets and computer animation known as CGI. The effects on the dinosaurs are fantastic and impeccable. I really love the T-Rex scene where it attacks Lex and Tim in the tour vehicle and injures one of the group including Ian Malcolm and killing Donald Gennaro. The Tyrannosaurus rex is something that people are in awe with including the effects on the dinosaurs and that goes with the triceratops. The triceratops is made out of robotic animatronics like all the other dinosaurs. It looks like you're looking at a real dinosaur. Stan Winston and his team did a fantastic job on the visual effects. The CGI is been used previously in The Abyss and Terminator 2: Judgment Day. Impressive, ain't it? The characters are really likeable and lovable and memorable. The actors did a really fantastic job on their portrayal on the characters. Sam Neill is Dr. Alan Grant is really good. He knows how dinosaurs extinct and what breed it is and does not like children but warms up to Lex and Tim, he's beginning to like children even more. He's such a great character. Laura Dern plays Dr. Ellie Sattler and that's all I can say about her. Jeff Goldblum plays Dr. Ian Malcolm who I think this character is a fan favourite by many people. He's a mathematician who specialise in chaos theory. Well, of course everybody knows the legendary Richard Attenborough as John Hammond. He passed away in a legendary age of 90. He's a billionaire philanthropist who Jurassic Park and the bioengineering company, InGen. He invites Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler to look at the cloning dinosaurs. He's a strong character. Two grandchildren, Lex and Tim who are John Hammond's grandchildren. They not annoying as many people said and that's how it works. Everybody remembers Samuel L. Jackson. I gotta say he says one line from which he said in Kong: Skull Island. "Hold on to your butts." The music I gotta say is absolutely beautiful. And you all know it's he legendary John Williams. He creates memorable music in many films he done in. The theme of Jurassic Park BLEW people away and it's becoming of the John Williams best piece of music in the generation of the life time and my favourite of all time along with Jaws. There's one scene that I do love is where you see the brachiosaurus for the first time and when you see it, it's CGI and it's breath-taking and it's so motherf***ing satisfying to look at. When John Hammond says a memorable line "Welcome to Jurassic Park." The music kicks in and you'll be in awe once you've seen the dinosaurs move in herds. Listen. This will never get out of your head every year every time you think about it. What can I say about Jurassic Park? Well, I gotta say, I love everything about it. I love the characters  the awesome story, fantastic special/visual effects, the directing style from one of my favourite directors of all time Steven Spielberg and the unforgettable music score by John Williams. You can't really go wrong, it is such an masterpiece! I can watch it over and over again without a fail and cannot deny it. It left me with awe and every time the Tyrannosaurus rex comes in and kills the raptors, it roars when the sign comes down saying "When dinosaurs ruled the earth.", it blew people away when they got out of the cinema years ago. Also, I would also recommend watching the special features and while you did that, you'll find a title called "The Making of Jurassic Park" and it's fantastic to look at. It's hosted by James Earl Jones and he tells that dinosaurs exist 65 million years ago. Jurassic Park is a biggest achievement for everyone who are in awe while they're in the roller coaster ride at the theme park. Good luck and welcome to Jurassic Park.

Awesome is a word that is thrown about gratuitously these days, but it is truly exemplified in one of director Steven Spielberg's many adventure hits. Deftly tying together thrilling action with prehistoric science fiction, Jurassic Park delivers terror like no film before it alongside an undercurrent of evolutionary philosophy. 

The cast plays the right notes throughout, providing comedy and drama in equal measure. Jeff Goldblum is his Goldblumian best as Ian Malcolm, while Sam Neill and Laura Dern play nicely both together and apart. Richard Attenborough is a very Crichtonesque character himself, no doubt influencing Anthony Hopkins' performance as Dr. Ford in the HBO TV series Westworld.

My biggest trifle (and admitted excuse) for watching few films from past decades is that I am concerned their older cinematography and technical direction would mar my ability to enjoy the film. However, some films can overcome all of that and enter the annals of film history. Jurassic Park is such a film, timeless and to be enjoyed for generations to come.
My Favorite movie of all time. The effects still hold up today. The is very enjoyable and an overall fun experience.

Strengths: It's Steven Spielberg at his finest. A big blockbuster movie that hits all the right notes. From a special effects standpoint, it's incredible. The film came out over two decades ago and looks better than most of what is produced in 2018. It looks that impressive. Spielberg's direction in this one is legendary. He's clearly having a blast with the wonder of having dinosaurs roam free. It's evident by some of his shots. Keeping with the more technical aspects of the film, John Williams provides one of the most memorable scores in cinema history. Sam Neil (Dr. Alan Grant) is a strong lead and the character being paired up with the kids was a smart move. He talks about not wanting kids throughout the film, but takes on a father figure role when things get tough, causing his growth. Jeff Goldblum (Dr. Ian Malcolm) is another standout from an acting perspective. Every scene is filled with something that matters, from character building to gorgeous shots to tense, pulse-pounding moments. It's a groundbreaking movie that is an absolute classic.

Weaknesses: Laura Dern (Dr. Ellie Sattier) is relatively fine in her role, but she doesn't bring much to the table. It feels like she's kind of just there. That's just nitpicking at this point, though.

Overall: I honestly forgot how great this was until I watched it again. There's a reason it's considered a classic. It has good writing and acting, but what makes it so incredible is everything else. The cinematography, the effects, and the terrific blend of horror, sci-fi, action, suspense, and even comedy.

One of the greatest ever films and the movie that truly ushered in the CGI revolution Jurassic Park is a milestone of not just storytelling but also special effects and sound engineering. I refuse to believe anyone who has not seen Jurassic park but if you happen to be in that minority I suggest you see this film on a rainy night with a great sound system. You will be blessed by the movie gods.

Director Steven Spielberg beautifully captures the magic of childlike wonderment of dinosaurs. These long extinct creatures feel real as you witness Spielberg's camera pan across fields and indoor environments alike. The practical effects and puppetry is still top tier and realistic as when this movie was first released. The CGI is starting to look dated, but when it is mixed with the practical effects, you cannot even tell the difference.

Although, Jurassic Park is overly long, you are entertained the entire movie. Jurassic Park remains as one of the most re-watchable films ever made. Families continue to pass this movie down generations as the effects still dazzle and the adventure still engages. Your sense of imagination is sparked by screeching dinosaurs and fearsome chase sequences. The moral parable aspect of Jurassic Park also still holds water as the ethical debate around controlling life with DNA and cloning conversation continues to this day.

John Williams' score is so memorable and truly inspires awe right when you reach the island. The tense quiet passages meet with the uplifting rousing theme. I cannot imagine this movie being as successful with another score.

The acting is pretty solid throughout. No one besides Sam Neill, Richard Attenborough, and Jeff Goldblum really deliver incredible feats of acting, but they are very emotive. I like Laura Dern in Jurassic Park, but I feel like she overacts at times. B.D. Wong, Samuel L. Jackson, and Wayne Knight all play their part perfectly believable to their characters. The kids can get annoying, but they are the audience's viewpoint into Jurassic Park. You are supposed to empathize with their experiences. I think they did a respectable job, but often come across as amateur. Overall, nice casting and decent acting from the ensemble for Jurassic Park.

In the end, Jurassic Park is a classic science fiction adventure with many horror elements thrown in from time to time. It will always be fun and well intentioned even as the CGI ages poorly. The practical effects persist as realistic though as does the set design. You really think that this theme park could exist at least while the movie is playing. It's a fun ride for sure while Spielberg has more impressive outings, Jurassic Park will always be a favorite to this critic.

There's a line in a trailer for the upcoming sequel Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom in which Chris Pratt's Owen Grady asks, "do you remember the first time you saw a dinosaur?"

I do.

It was twenty-five years ago, back in 1993, when I watched the original Jurassic Park in theaters for the first time. I was nine years old, and the dinosaurs seemed so real. It wasn't so much the CGI, though that was state-of-the-art and holds up shockingly well. It was the wonder of seeing something for the first time, the spectacle and power of prehistoric life on the big screen.

With that in mind, and the imminent arrival of said sequel, it felt more than appropriate to revisit Jurassic Park as it celebrates its silver jubilee.

The movie was such a landmark, its easy to forget it was based on an equally successful book by Michael Crichton. The relatively simple story didn't change much from page to screen. You all know it anyway:

Idealistic promoter recreates hundreds of dinosaurs with preserved mosquito blood; group of scientists travels to exotic island for sneak peak at theme park of the resurrected beasts; things go terribly wrong; those visitors that don't get eaten spend the remaining time running and screaming.

It's funny-based on this description, the movie sounds like a disposable piece of horror schlock. Nothing could be further from the truth. But how?

Let's start with the most obvious reason-it was directed by Steven Spielberg. And this at a time when he was in his prime, the king of Hollywood. He'd already made Jaws and E.T., and still had future hits like Saving Private Ryan and Lincoln to come. But while he delivered with expected, well-rounded expertise, there's one aspect of Spielberg's approach that's worth highlighting above all others.

It stems from the fact that Jurassic Park the novel is darker and more violent than the movie. In fact, James Cameron (The Terminator, Aliens) nearly nabbed the rights to direct the film instead. By his own admission, his version would've been more intense and graphic-closer to the source material, and almost certainly rated R.

That would've been interesting, but hardly suitable for most nine-year-olds. That's where Spielberg comes in. As with Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Raiders of the Lost Ark and War of the Worlds, he possesses the special ability to create tension for all ages. Whether a child or adult, when you watch his movies your pulse is racing, nerves consistently brought to the brink but never over the edge. You leave the theater not afraid, but exhilarated, a smile of sheer energy spread across your face.

But he doesn't do it alone. There are so many other reasons why, a quarter-century later, Jurassic Park still feels new. Take John Williams' legendary score, which nearly upstaged the dinosaurs themselves and remains popular today. Or the way David Koepp's underrated script peppers in saving doses of humor ("I'm always on the lookout for the next ex-Mrs. Malcolm").

Who were Sam Neill, Laura Dern and Jeff Goldblum before this movie? Certainly not household names. They were never really movie stars, either. Instead, they were-and are-skilled actors that lend Jurassic Park an envious on-screen pedigree among summer blockbusters. And despite many modern complaints of 'annoying' child stars, Ariana Richards and Joseph Mazzello have consistently avoided such a label. The credit is theirs, displaying a genuine combination of fascination and fear, making them simply what every actor hopes to be-part of the movie.

Like Star Wars, Terminator 2 and Toy Story, Jurassic Park broke technological ground. But also like those movies, it connected with its audience beyond mere scale and pixels. This is why, twenty-five years later, we keep coming back to the original. And why its next twenty-five will roar just as loudly.

Knocking It Out of the Park

It's been 25 years since Spielberg's dino saga changed movie making with it's fabulous CGI monsters. Amazingly, they still hold up and look great. But what makes JP a 5* effort is the amazing suspense and technically great film making.

Based on a script by Michael Crichton and David Koepp from the novel by Crichton, it starts off a bit slow, but the moment Nedry the computer nerd (Wayne Knight, unforgettable) turns off the power so that he can steal some dino embryos, the film pulsates with pace, aggression and genuine terror. The archeologist protagonist, Sam Neil, goes on a journey of self discovery to become the ideal father - by saving the awful John Hammond's (Richard Attenborough) grandchildren from Hammond's dino creations. Some critics criticised Spielberg for only killing off the minor characters while providing plot armour for the leads and the children - but imagine what the movie would have been like if the dinos were allowed to feast on Laura Dern or the poor kids. It would have been totally uncommercial and a much worse story. Instead, the kids in peril make the best suspense, whether trapped in the SUV while the T-Rex attacks, or the kitchen scene with the Velociraptors. These are great scenes, and there is enough blood shed  in the dino eating scenes to satisfy all but the most gruesome tastes. 

Not enough credit goes to the cast - of course Neil is solid, Dern is feisty, Attenborough full of remorse, Jeff Goldblum is fantastic, his barbed scepticism and wit makes the whole thing resonate and still relevant. 

And George Lucas's ILM provide the special effects, the first really fabulous CGI, to lift the dinos from lumps of plastic to really scary monsters. There is seamless integration between the real and CGI in this that makes his Star Wars prequels look so disappointingly unreal. But here, they are fantastic. 

Hats off to Speilberg, the greatest film storyteller of the late 20th and early 21st Century. This really is one of his suspense masterpieces and  a beacon of bravura filmmaking.

Who said newer means better? Steven Spielberg's  masterpiece summer blockbuster Jurassic Park proves that even a film from 1993 can stand toe to toe with some of today's biggest movies. Even in 2017, the realism captured with these dinosaurs is astounding. The way Spielberg combined incredible CGI and practical creatures, making them blend seamlessly with one another still amazes me. Jurassic Park isn't just a really fun dinosaur movie, from a characterization and storytelling standpoint, the film excels. It has likable characters (most notably Ian Malcolm and Muldoon), each with their own distinct personalities, and an absolutely riveting story which still keeps me hooked from beginning to end. The first two or three scenes are just a little dragging, but the film soon picks up. The T-Rex breakout scene, the velociraptors in the kitchen, and the first time we see the dinosaurs are three of cinema's best moments, all in one film. It even provides a somewhat scientifically sound reason for the whole concept to be plausible (and yes, when a PhD in genetics or paleontology examines it, there are sure to be dozens of plot holes, but at least they tried). Jurassic Park is a masterpiece, even in 2017.

Edit Contribution in Jurassic Park
For all or any who have not yet seen this 1993 Blockbuster I urge you to look it up. This films special effects are dazzling and at more moments than not still terrifying. Not only that but the actors and their acting is far above par. This Action film is a great movie and has truly captivated audiences for decades. However, this review is more about the editing in the film. 
There are many parts that go into the making of a movie but editing is always a large
part of making said movie.  It is perhaps most needed in movies with large animatronics and special effects. An example using this film could be how the editing between a T-rex and Jeff Goldblum invokes a sense of fear even from sitting on a couch. The Aesthetics used in the film are indeed works of wonder, however the masterful way in which they are edited are what truly give this film its terrifying and awe inspiring emotional response. The editing of the film allows the seemingly flawless transitions from character to character to dinosaur allowing these incredible actors to deliver their lines majestically. I would have to say however that one series of scenes in particular have phenomenal editing. (SPOILERS for this 1993 movie) The scene I am talking about comes at the end of the movie when the T-rex faces off against the raptors while the main protagonists escape. The edits make this battle of epic proportions truly come to life, whether it be the fighting or fleeing. 
Kossak, 2
	The Area Studies and Film was a bit lacking having no other languages aside from English during the film, despite its references to other regions. Just as well there isn't much backstory given about the characters. Unless you count dinosaurs themselves as backstory, then yes, it gives a lot. It also had an aspect ratio of 1:85:1 as to accommodate for the dinosaur animatronics. The film also set a new standard in the Art Cinema category with its incredible CGI and animatronics. 
	Finally, after talking about some technical aspects of the film, as well as the editing. The overall rating, I would have to give this film would be a 9.5. It stands the test of time and Truly deserves its academy awards.

Today, 25 years after the release of the novel and 22 years after the first film, Universal Studios releases the latest blockbuster in the the Jurassic Park series, Jurassic World. While this new film is not based on a book, I thought it would be fun to take a look at the original Jurassic Park adaptation. Released in 1993 and based on the novel by author Michael Crichton, Jurassic Park was a groundbreaking summer blockbuster that shattered box office records and set a new standard for special effects in film.

By now, I think it is safe to say that almost everyone has seen Jurassic Park, or is at least familiar with the premise of the film. Like the novel, the film follows the story of an amusement park that is designed to display the fruits of a landmark scientific discovery. Through a painstaking process of collecting dinosaur DNA from petrified mosquitoes, scientists at InGen, led by John Hammond, are able to bring the extinct animals to life. Hammond's lawyers see enormous profitability, but urge him to have experts attest to the safety of the park. Hammond brings in Dr. Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler, paleontologists, and mathematician and chaos theorist Dr. Ian Malcolm to tour the park and provide their expert recommendations.

When the group of scientists first set eyes on the dinosaurs of the park, they experience awe and wonder at seeing the incredible creatures. In 1993, and I'd argue still to this day, the audience shares in these feelings. The buildup is perfectly timed to the fantastic payoff of finally seeing the animals on screen. Add to this the fact that Jurassic Park marks the first time CGI was ever used to create animals on film, and you can understand the power and historical significance of this moment. But this moment is not meant to last. As the film continues, all of the failsafe, man-made systems begin to malfunction and the animals begin to overtake the island.

In the hands of director Steven Spielberg, Jurassic Park is elevated from B-movie horror to a thoughtful commentary on morality in science. To be fair, the movie is pure escapist entertainment at its finest. The large set pieces are expertly crafted and the film plays as everything audiences have come to expect from a big-budget summer blockbuster. Still, on a larger level, the film questions the power of science and dares to show both the magnificent and terrifying effects it can have. In the end, it is a lack of respect for the science that leads to the human's demise. This disregard for consequence in favor of profit and entertainment, also brings forth an interesting point. After 20 years, Jurassic Park remains the pinnacle of an effects driven movie. Spielberg manages to strike the perfect balance in the film, employing effects that truly serve the story. As we find ourselves now with every blockbuster film saturated in CGI effects, it is interesting to note that this film, which had far less access to the technology that filmmakers currently enjoy, remains far superior to many of the films that have followed it (even two sequels). It is the respect of the filmmakers for the science at their disposal that makes the story and film one of the most enjoyable blockbusters of all time.

There are so many reasons why this Spielberg classic works and why it still holds up to this date. It is a thought-provoking film that talks about man vs. nature; it is a terrific popcorn entertainment film with some of the most thrilling and terrifying sequences ever put on film. But above all, this is a film about family. It has characters you actually care about, characters whom you can identify with. It has a strong emotional core and that is the strength of "Jurassic Park". Watching it again for the first time in a decade made me realize how much practical effects were used in this visually revolutionary film. The film's only weakness is the two child actors. They annoyed the hell out of me the first time I saw it, and they still annoyed me this time too. But other than that, this is a really great film. Awe-inspiring, terrifying, and it's directed to near perfection. It's a cinematic triumph.

Quality: 7.5/10
Content: 6/10
Before Jurassic World and two other sequels, there was Jurassic Park twenty-two years ago. It's good, to say the least, but not great -- well-made, but a typical action flick at its core. Though Spielberg really wished to induce amazement, he introduced the dinosaurs quite too early, mollifying the awe the characters - whom we have known for no more than ten minutes - display (and we should have felt). Based on the renowned Michael Crichton novel, Spielberg, David Keopp, and Crichton himself cut the story down to a simple and bloody nightmare.

We meet Dr. Grant, a dinosaur paleontologist (a power-filled performance by Sam Neil), and his fiancée and assistant, Dr. Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern) working on a dinosaur excavation site. In a surprise visit, a mysterious, eccentric billionaire park owner, John Hammond (Richard Attenborough), asks the two renowned archaeologists to endorse his new yet-to-launch, live dinosaur park. As they arrive at the park situated on a private island, they are joined by a mathematician Dr. Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum), the "blood-sucking" lawyer Gennaro (Martin Ferraro) representing Hammond's investors, and Hammond's two grandchildren, Lex and Tim. But then, just as a foreseeing Dr. Malcolm observes, the park goes amuck due to the betrayal of the only IT guy capable of running the park.

The whole film can be enfolded by an exchange with the mathematician Dr. Malcolm first declaring: "God creates dinosaurs. God destroys dinosaurs. God creates man. Man destroys God. Man creates dinosaurs." To which Dr. Ellie Sattler replies: "Dinosaurs eat man. Woman inherits the earth." First, this story portrays man's destruction of God by creating dinosaurs; man became God and created and ruled their creations as a god, but what they created was superior to them. Secondly, Spielberg involves a forced female lead whose acting falls short of the magnitude of her role. Sure, strong female leads are great, but Laura Dern portrays Sattler as almost weak and gives overdone and exaggerated expressions radically different than her fiancé's near grim looks and demeanor. Even Dr. Malcolm could not see the chemical reaction between the couple.

Granted, this is considered one of the most frightening movies ever made. But deeper than the action and near escapes are the themes of paternal love. The grim Dr. Alan Grant never truly smiles, never has a genuine, good laugh over anything and above all, enormously despises children. However, chance intervenes when Mr. Hammond brings his grandchildren along to be the first visitors to the not-yet launched park. But when everything goes amuck in the park and Gennaro ditches the children in an act of cowardliness, Grant bravely but reluctantly takes them into his custody, who in turn treat him to the joys of parenthood. 

Some of you may have even seen it in theatres in its release and noticed that the "theater shook." Not surprisingly, Jurassic Park was the first major movie to use surround sound (simply sound that surrounds), bringing the petrifying sounds of the Jurassic period to the screen. With cars smothered in blood and gore, bodies eaten as fast as anchovies and intense struggle of man against his creation, no wonder Jurassic Park has such a bloodstained name on it. The language is no better; expletives drop as fast as the bodies. But cowardliness is avenged, and Dr. Grant finds his own fatherly instinct. Definitely, Jurassic Park is satisfying and the events frightening, but it falls away from the strength and complexity of the original novel.

"Jurassic Park" is another one of "Steven Spielberg's" classics. "Jurassic Park" is an amazing Sci-Fi/Fantasy movie of 1993. The plot to "Jurassic Park" is that a group of miners discover a mosquito frozen in tree sap from millions of years ago. Later a group of scientists get a hold of this they suck out the blood that the mosquito took from animals. The scientists discover that the mosquito had been carrying dinosaur D.N.A. The scientist then uses the D.N.A. to create living dinosaurs. But what the scientists don't know is shortly all hell will break loose. The plot to the movie is superb; the intro to the film is a thrilling and suspenseful opening to what will happen. During the movie we get to love "Alan Grant" portrayed by "Sam Neill" who is a caring person. "Jurassic Park" uses humour to make the movie even better; it is very successful at this. The acting in "Jurassic Park" is superb, "Richard Attenborough" and "Laura Dern" are perfect actors, the don't oversell their performances or have weak performances. "Steven Spielberg" and "John Williams" constantly work together to create some of cinema's very best music. The music "John Williams" created was extremely suspenseful. It may not be the very best he's done but it's still is great to listen to. For a movie made in 1993 using C.G.I. everywhere it would be expected that the special effects would look horrible to today's standards. The C.G.I. is excellent it's barely noticeable. "Steven Spielberg" is the master at directing and filming movies; "Jurassic Park" was filmed exceptionally. The scene where the dinosaur is chasing the car looks magnificent. If you are a person who enjoys "Spielberg" movies or Sci-Fi movies than I highly recommend you watch "Jurassic Park" as it is a classic, with amazing acting and stunning visuals. I give "Jurassic Park" a 9/10. The movie did have some issues, some scenes dragged on for a while, C.G.I. was great but a bit out of date.

What is even more amazing is the fact that in 2015 THEY STILL LOOK REAL, Jurassic Park was light years ahead of its time, and honestly, still is.
