It's possible that Jurassic Park is solely responsible for my love of horror films.
 
I can easily recall a seven year-old version of myself squirming and shrinking into a ball on the hard theatre seat during the opening sequence. I pulled the collar of my shirt up to my eyes and hoped the wailing raptor in that containment unit wouldn't escape right through the screen and into my lap. The night was dark, the wind was wild, and the enemy was waiting just around the corner. I was thrilled, and this moment created a life-long hunger for more.
 
Let it be known that I'm no fan of the summer blockbuster film, especially these days. Typically they are lazy, bland, and take no risks. I was pleased while re-watching Jurassic Park to be reminded of the pre-Michael Bay years when the big summer action film possessed brains in equal measure to its CGI muscle. 
 
Speaking of which, how do the visual effects in this film still look so good? The Phantom Menace was released six years after JP and those computer effects already look extremely dated. Aside from the technology being used in the cars and control center everything here stands up. Jurassic Park could be released today and inspire as much awe as it did  in 1993.
 
There's nothing really to critique here, the film is a classic for a reason. Well cast, written, and acted with outstanding visual effects and near perfect pacing. There's drama, tension, action, and humor but, more importantly, Jurassic Park respects its audience. I'm a real asshole about movies but admit to being thrilled and joyfully entertained by this film so many years after first seeing it.
 
All praise withstanding I must also acknowledge that it feels a lot like Raiders of the Lost Ark with dinosaurs. Sam Neill is Indy without the sex appeal and Spielberg has replaced the boulder chase with a charging t-rex. Who could blame him? It ain't broke.

I feel like I am supposed to love Jurassic Park, but I was fairly disappointed.  I am 22 years late and I know that the special effects were monumental at the time of its release.  Indeed they were, because Jurassic Park took home three 1994 Academy Awards for Best Sound Effects Editing, Best Visual Effects, and Best Sound.  The problem is that the dinosaurs are the best part of the movie; the screenplay flops, the character development is absent, the plot is weak, and the novel leaves the film in the dust.  I felt like I waited in a long line for the "best roller-coaster ever," finally got on the ride, did a couple turns, and got off thinking, "That was it?"

One of the biggest (and best) Hollywood blockbusters of all time. It's easy to nitpick the minor details about this movie, and overlook the little nuances showcased by Stephen Spielberg that made him one of the best directors of all time. This is probably the biggest movie at a time when he was at the top of his game.

The plot itself is silly. It's basic King Kong kind of stuff. The acting is negligible when you're basically required to run away from CGI dinosaurs.

But the visual effects, the shots, the pacing. It all wraps up so perfectly. The reason the CGI is still hailed today (even though it actually does look worse than modern CGI) is because they used it minimally and effectively. The t-rex looks amazing because most of the CGI is done in a night setting with tons of rain. There's a mix between animatronics and CGI that is edited seamlessly together to give the illusion of real dinosaurs. Spielberg also doesn't overexpose the dinosaurs. We see plenty of them, but the raptors for example don't even appear until over midway through the movie. The t-rex has big scenes, but only shows up at key scenes (three scenes only).

And to top it all off, it's actually better than the book. Okay, maybe not "better" (that's kind of subjective in this case), but the movie is much tighter and well paced than the book. And the changes made from the book are actually improvements. The ending is much more satisfying.

If you go into this movie for the story, you'll be slightly let down. It's good and imaginative, but it's very silly too. But if you go in this movie for the spectacle and to see one of the best directors of all time at his peak? This is a must-see.

I remember having a conversation with my cousin, asking him why Jurassic Park intrigued him if his priority when it comes to film is good character development. He said it has good philosophical discussion, and he pointed out the scene he was referring to: the "life finds a way" scene, and I had forgotten this gem within the movie. And recently a friend of mine pointed out that Dr. Grant ties two female ends of seat belts together to strap himself in which is a great metaphor for this motif of the dinosaurs supposedly being all female.

These philosophical aspects, including the amazing scene focusing on a debate of whether it is responsible to try to add dinosaurs back into the swing of things altogether, raise the movie up higher than the mere B movie critics believe it to be. But is there anything wrong with the overall fun and excitement of this seemingly simple people? We see dinosaurs on-screen for the first time in a much different way - both with the use of animatronics and digitally. We also have the quirky characters such as Wayne Knight and Jeff Goldblum's characters to add to the fun.

The film is pretty aware of itself, making references to King Kong and displaying the dinosaurs as a spectacle to future park-goers, just as the idea of the effects to make the dinosaurs are a spectacle to us as movie-goers. It also draws attention to its potential horror towards little kids with Dr. Grant illustrating the idea of a velociraptor to a cocky kid, and the grandkids that tag along for the park ride that are shown screaming on-screen.

Jurassic Park is a classic Science fiction adventure film that delivers loads of stunning moments and it is by far Steven Spielberg's best film ever made. Based on the novel of the same name by Michael Crichton Jurassic Park follows two dinosaur experts Sam Neill's Dr. Alan Grant and Laura Dern's Dr. Ellie as they are invited by eccentric millionaire John Hammond to preview his new amusement park on an island off Costa Rica by cloning DNA harvested from pre historic insects where Hammond creates living dinosaurs for his new attraction known as Jurassic Park where tourists gets to see lots of dinosaurs that were extinct many years ago. But soon one of the employees turns against Hammond by messing with the park's system which results with the dinosaurs escaping. And soon Dr. Alan Grant and Richard Hammond's grandchildren must escape the island as all the dinosaurs wreck havoc in the park. When I first heard of the Jurassic Park series right after watching the fourth film in the Jurassic Park series Jurassic World. I became so interested with the Jurassic Park movies and when I finally got the chance to watch the original Jurassic Park I was stunned and amazed. Seriously, Jurassic Park is one of the best films about dinosaurs and it is my personal favorite Steven Spielberg film since Poltergeist. It is so cool how Steven Spielberg created such an amazing movie that everyone will never forget. What I love about Jurassic Park is that this movie is seriously intriguing from start to finish and it is the film that can seriously entertain both kids and adults at the same time and the overall concept is very intriguing and cool. The other things I like about this movie is how Spielberg created the film and he was able to execute the movie in a very good way there is nothing dull with it at all, everything in this movie is perfect thanks also to the screenplay by David Koepp and Michael Crichton himself. The movie is also full of so many scenes that are so memorable and very intense, plus suspenceful at the same time(The opening sequence, the marvelous sequence where the dinosaur egg hatched, the first appearance of the T-Rex, The scene where the T-Rex attempts its first attack, the super thrilling sequence with the car hanging in the tree, scenes with the raptors, the intense electric fence scene and the finale where the T-Rex saves the day). The other Highlights of the film is the settings of the movie and I love the look and feel of the film, it feels as if the park is there and it really exists at the same time. It gives the movie the feeling that you are in the park because the park looks so beautiful and gorgeous at the same time, plus the Jurassic Park theme song(which was used also in some of the sequels) is so heartwarming and the cinematography is beautiful and we get to see loads of wonderful and glorious views within the film itself and there are loads of magnificent landscapes and tight shots at the same time. But the true main highlight of this movie is the dinosaurs and the special effects itself. I love all of the dinosaurs in this movie and my personal favorite dinosaur in the film is the T-Rex and the raptors they are by far the most terrifying dinosaurs in the movie while I also love the other dinosaurs like the Bracheosaurus, Triceratops etc... and the effects itself are so amazing and beautiful. The idea of combining animatronics and CGI makes the look of the dinosaurs look so realistic and I love how the dinosaurs were designed in the film and the way they move is so realistic as well. Plus the CGI is so top notch I would definitely say that Jurassic Park is also the film that introduced CGI. This is an example of a movie that handles the CGI properly and every special effect worked really well in the film at the same time, it seriously gave the film a strong feel and of course a proper look thanks to the movie's impressive quality we get an excellent movie with a proper execution. Now the acting is superb, all of the casts in this movie did an amazing job with their work on this movie and all of them deliver the best performances in film history. Sam Neill did an amazing job with his performance as Dr. Alan Grant the same can be said to Laura Dern as Dr. Ellie Alan Grant's partner and girlfriend. The late Richard Attenborough delivers one of his best performances ever as Richard Hammond the park owner, the same can be said to Jeff Goldblum as Ian Malcolm and its also nice to see Samuel L. Jackson in one of his earliest and best performance before he portrayed Nick Fury in the Marvel Cinematic Universe while the rest of the casts did an amazing job with their performances as well. Director Steven Spielberg created an extraordinary and thrilling movie that captures the heart and strength of every kid who wants to learn about dinosaurs and Spielberg managed to turn David Koepp and Michael Crichton's screenplay into a beautiful movie with loads of memorable moments and it also acts as one of the best films of the 90's at the same time. Overall Jurassic Park is a fun and superb Adventure film that delivers loads of thrills and tension from start to finish and this is the best installment in the Jurassic Park series since Jurassic World. This movie gets a 10.5/10.

Steven Spielberg is one of the greatest directors of all time. To this day, Schindler's List is-in my humble opinion-his best film. Spielberg has produced so many iconic movies in the past thirty years, including Jaws, Raiders of the Lost Ark, and E.T. He is one of the kings of special and practical effects. He has made a profound impact on me as an aspiring filmmaker. "Jurassic Park'' is the iconic adventure film-directed by Spielberg. It's considered by many to be one of-if not his best-movies made. It stars Sam Neill, Laura Dern, Jeff Goldblum, Richard Attenborough, and Samuel L. Jackson.

During a desert excavation, Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neil) and Dr. Ellie Sattler (Dern) are unexpectedly visited. The visitor is John Hammond (Attenborough), director of bioengineering company, InGen. Hammond has come to offer Grant and Sattler a trip to his dinosaur theme park: Jurassic Park. Agreeing to come with, the two paleontologists are amazed at the real life dinosaurs that await them. In the lab, they discover that scientists have been breeding and creating dinos. Somewhat suspicious of the project, Hammond offers them a special tour of the theme park. Not far into the tour, Grant and Sattler come across sick dinosaurs. Many of the stops on their trip are vacant of any dinosaur activity. Unfortunately, a t-rex has been causing problems all over the park, and the tourists must struggle to stay alive when an unexpected visitor breaks through the fence.

This film is widely considered to be a kind of cult classic-and it really is one. I've never had so much fun watching a film like I did watching this one. First of all, the characters are really likable. Alan Grant is the steadfast leader. He knows all about dinosaurs and their behavior, giving him an advantage when trying to survive. Accompanying Grant are two children who love dinosaurs, yet are naturally very afraid of them. It was really sentimental when Grant was teaching the kids about the dinosaurs. Previously in the film, he stated that he and his wife didn't wish to have children, so the bonding that they shared was really heartwarming. However, my favorite character in the film had to be Dr. Ian Malcolm. He was really witty and funny, delivering some of the most memorable lines in the movie.

I can imagine what it was like sitting in the theater in 1993, watching this movie for the first time. It must have been an incredible experience. The special effects are really incredible. In this day and age, it's easy to not appreciate visual effects, and especially practical effects. We are so acostumned to great visuals that we aren't as impressed by them.  However, look at the stunning visuals in James Cameron's, Avatar or in Dawn of the Planet of the Apes. This film has an amazing animatronic t-rex. It was a heart pounding thrill ride from beginning to end. 

As an action adventure film, this is one of the best I've ever seen. Spielberg directs the film so well. The script is full of fantastic humor and dialogue, as well as quirky and memorable characters. Spielberg and composer John Williams have been working together for years, and his score for this film is just as memorable and iconic as his previous work with the director. 

"Jurassic Park" is a bit cheesy, and some of the special effects (CGI) are somewhat outdated. Nevertheless, this is an impressive film for it's time. It's funny, well written, and visually inventive. Spielberg's theme park adventure film is something anyone can enjoy, young and old. It's a cult classic-some would even say a masterpiece-that has stood the test of time.

Michael Crichton broke incredible ground with Jurassic Park the novel. Combining cutting-edge science with a believable premise and an intriguing message made for some truly spectacular reading in book form. If you have not yet read the book, I urge you to do so, as the suspense is excellent, and the story feels more complete.

Spielberg has made an excellent film here. Weaving the science-heavy story in with stunning visuals is tricky enough, but he manages do develop the human characters, and keep the threat of dinosaurs all too real. There is a great tonal shift, as the beginning of the film is awe-inspiring and optimistic, but this gives way to a horror feel at a certain point. This is not a horror film per se, neither is it a 'creature-feature'.

There is a mix of acting here. Sam Neill doesn't sell it too well here, and the kids are kind of annoying. Laura Dern is good, showing her character's sunny disposition. Richard Attenborough plays Hammond well, and Jeff Goldblum makes Ian Malcom memorable.

This is the film that inspired a whole generation of dinosaur fans. It has a cool premise, great visuals, and a suspenseful story that never loses sight of its message.
If I could I would rate it more than 5 stars

Jurassic Park is a blockbuster film, and blockbuster that is done very well indeed. It's the kind of movie where you might see the synopsis and think it looks like seen before film, but this is different in a few ways. The emotion that runs through is beautiful, not to mention the thrills the dinosaurs give you too, the characters first view of the dinosaurs is fantastic and well acted, the park so well designed 

Steven Spielberg is the mind behind the picture and he commands this in a way any big budget director can only dream of emulating. He seems to just know what to do, in every scene, and to be fair say what you say about the script in this one, Spielberg bashes out a film that probably doesn't even need a decent script. And on to that script, Spielberg gets everything he can out of it. He absolutely pulls it all out and even if fans of the original Michael Crichton novel dislike this, you can't deny Spielberg does well.

For me there are two stand out performances, Sam Neill and Richard Attenborough. First of all Neill as Palaeontologist Dr Alan Grant is good, he seems to make this film more personal and less big budget, he brings you closer to the characters and just does his job well. Attenborough is just fine in his role John Hammond, owner of the Jurassic park. He knows what he is doing, a fine performance from a true great and he makes this movie even more memorable too.

I think this is just good fun, don't take the whole plot too seriously and you will massively enjoy this, this isn't a major award winner type movie but bits an pieces maybe do deserve great recognition. The effects used are just fantastic, and this is for 1993 as well, just top top work and really set a bar in my opinion. The animatronics of the dinosaurs are so well done, so well designed and so well, well moved in a sense. The animals are scary in this, not overly so don't fear for the kids being frightened, but it might just a little. 

I think reason this is such a classic is the way in which it can just be pretty slow and un-eventful then BOOM!, suddenly a huge T-Rex is running round or smashing the hell out of a car or something, it's actually good fun. It's characters like Jeff Goldblum's who make this funny and less serious, he cracks jokes at the scariest of times and some of his one two's with Sam Neill and Laura Dern(Ellie Sattler) are just brilliant. I think yet again Steven Spielberg directs the actors in a way that suits this movie brilliantly, they just blend well and Spielberg gets the absolute most out of them.

If you want a serious kind of drama movie(that somehow includes dinosaurs), then don't watch this, but If you want crazy all out thrills, with good acting, special effects and of course directing, this is all for you. I couldn't recommend this more to people, it is just such a good adventure, so well cast and the chemistry between everyone is just great, and again here comes that word, fun.

Overall an incredible movie, for me possibly one of the best of all time, definitely one of the best thrillers and the number one dinosaur based movie by miles. Give it a go and see if like me you find this amazing, and then you'll see just how much attention you'll give this film.

Jurassic Park is, without a doubt, one of my favorite movies of all time.  If I made a list of my favorite movies Jurassic Park would be in the top ten or even top five.  It's an amazing experience that everyone should see if you love cinema.  The characters are great and fun, it's grand, it's suspenseful, and the effects look monumental.  These are among some of the best effects I've seen on film.  
The music is also iconic and has a lot to do with why the film is as good as it is.  John Williams, in my opinion, is the greatest composer to come out of Hollywood.  He's done some of the most iconic themes in movies.  You have Jurassic Park, The Lost World, The Star Wars films, The Indiana Jones films, Superman The Movie, Home Alone, among others.  He is a legend in the world of music.
The cast is great as well.  I often feel like these people are very underappreciated.  Of everyone in the cast the one who has gone on to do the most by far is Samuel L. Jackson.  Jeff Goldblum was big for a bit after this film but he pretty much went nowhere by the 2000s.  He also gets a lot of shit from critics now which I feel is undeserved as I actually like him as an actor.  
Sam Neil hasn't done much either in the 2000s at least as far as American films go.  He's done some TV shows which went nowhere.  I feel he's one of the most underappreciated actors as he's personally one of my favorites.  
The same applies with Laura Dern who's probably one of my favorite actresses.  Richard Attenborough also does a great job as John Hammond.  He is greatly missed.  The rest of the cast does good work as well.
Overall, if you want a grand and epic experience or just want to see a great monster movie than here you are.  Hell, if you're a fan of dinosaurs in general than this is the movie to watch.  This and Land Before Time made me fascinated with dinosaurs as a kid.  It was one of my favorite films then and now.

The only negative aspects are that the CGI is a bit vague (and the practical effects) and that it took too long for the movie to really start. But also that the ending was a bit too sudden. But it's still an awesome movie.

Since the latter half of the twenty century, each decade has one film that captures the imagination of the whole world and makes audiences stare at awe: The 60´s had "2001 A Space Odyssey", the 70´s saw the release of the original "Star Wars", the 80´s audiences were touched by "E.T." and the 90´s witness the birth of one of the most useful and expensive tools in cinema -CGI- in the beloved "Jurassic Park".
John Hammond is an old billionaire who has managed to recreate the DNA of Mesozoic creatures and attempts to build a zoo where people for all around the world could see this majestic creatures. 
By now "Jurassic Park" has become one of those films that have made their mark in the childhood of countless people, so it would be easy to assume that the only reason this film is hailed as a "modern classic" is due to that nostalgic feel but this statement couldn't be more wrong. "Jurassic Park" is a film that has everything that a classic needs: Memorable and likable characters, unforgettable sequences, an iconic soundtrack by the always reliable John Williams, Spielberg´s directing is a mash up of his heartwarming personal style that made "E.T." worked and his intense/suspenseful style that made "Jaws" the classic it is, the acting is extremely fun to watch, the character relationships are believable and the soul of this film, special effects that are immune to the test of time as they still look impressive and breathtaking, a pacing that can go from a peppy feeling to a nail-biting experience, Spielberg delivers his trademark visuals by creating impressive and unforgettable shots, themes that work regardless of the fact that they feel ham-fisted, memorable dialog and a script so well written that it delivers exposition so quickly/efficiently and knows when to show the creatures. Today, there are some people that consider this film an "overrated generic Hollywood blockbuster with a Spielberg touch" and they have a point as this film has been imitated to death in the last twenty years but this is a summer blockbuster done right due to all the elements I mentioned before. 
"Jurassic Park" is definitely a film that lives up its enormous reputation of a modern classic. While this is by no means one of Spielberg´s greatest films, it is one of his best blockbusters. Arguably one of the greatest blockbusters ever made. An unforgettable film that will continue to impress audiences in years to come.

Since we're only a couple of days away from the premiere of Jurassic World I wanted to share some thoughts on one of my all time favorite movie going experiences (perhaps my favorite). I was only 12 years old when Steven Spielberg released Jurassic Park in 1993 and from the second the movie started I was at the edge of my seat. From the breathtaking and groundbreaking visuals, to the outstanding cast, and the magnificent score everything about Jurassic Park made me fall in love with it. The dinosaurs had come to life before my very eyes, and Spielberg masterfully wrote a thrilling script that had me sweating for two full hours. I can never forget the thrills I felt during the T-rex scene and that final climax with the velociraptors in the museum's kitchen. I remember thinking there was no one cooler than Sam Neill's Alan Grant and I wanted to be Tim Murphy (played brilliantly by Joseph Mazzello). The rest of the cast was also amazing: Laura Dern, Jeff Goldblum, Richard Attenborough, Ariana Richards, Bob Peck, and Samuel L. Jackson. Many will consider Jaws as Steven Spielberg's most terrifying film, but for me it was Jurassic Park because I got to experience it on the big screen and it was my first memorable experience at a theater. I had seen many other films that had made an impact on me prior to this (Star Wars, The Goonies, Raiders of the Lost Arc, and E.T.) but none in a theater, so Jurassic Park holds that nostalgic value and it will forever remain one of my favorite films. It also became the first film I went to see again at a theater because I couldn't get enough of this world. There are so many quotable lines from this movie and many memorable scenes, and I realize it is going to be impossible for Jurassic World to live up to that standard but I am still highly anticipating it while I relive some of my childhood memories with Jurassic Park. It's a masterpiece.

Jurassic Park is one of Spielberg's best films, and one of the best sci-fi disaster films of all time. It takes a concept that could have been a simple B-movie, and brings it to life as something more.

The plot revolves around a man who brings scientists to endorse his new and creation -- a theme park where the attractions are cloned dinosaurs. However, an attempt to smuggle dinosaur DNA, leads to a power outage. The dinosaurs break free, and everybody's lives are in danger.

The film was revolutionary at the time for it's special effects. This movie popularized the use of CGI by showing dinosaurs that looked very realistic. And more than twenty years later, amazingly, the effects still hold up today.

Now if there's one thing that director Steven Spielberg is good at, it's putting a sense of childlike wonder in his films, and this is prevalent in the first half hour of this film. This shows the park in all of it's majesty, before things went horribly wrong. The dinosaurs all look amazing, and it keeps you dazzled and entertained even before anything bad happens. You'll probably want to actually go to the park... I mean besides the whole getting killed by dinosaurs thing.

When the s--t does hit the fan, it is very intense. These scenes done in a very different manner than what he had done with his breakout film, Jaws. In Jaws, the shark was rarely shown, and this made the sequences it was in more tense. In this movie, he shows the dinosaurs in all of their glory. This method usually doesn't work in movies, but this is one of the few exceptions. The direction of these sequences keep tensions high as the people try to escape.

In conclusion, Jurassic Park is a classic, that stays intense and spectacular throughout. The visuals are amazing, the action is thrilling, and the direction is great. In short, yes, it's as good as you probably remember.

Crichton = Thriller, Spielberg = Adventure

This is one of those issues where reading the book before seeing the movie is going to give you a different perspective on things. I read Michael Crichton's novel first, and enjoyed it much more than Spielberg's movie.

Crichton wrote a very R-rated thriller that was dark and terrifying. You felt like you were trapped on that island with those people. And, instead of off-screen or "Godzilla"-like violence, Crichton had people getting eviscerated, etc. In the movie, Spielberg and screenwriter David Koepp (who I think is AWFUL!), have Tyrannosaurs miraculously saving people and so on. 

In the novel, people are trapped in the dark, having to use their wits to survive. The bottom line is that the novel is a hard-core thriller, and the movie is an adventure film.

So, if the adventure thing works best for you, then you're in luck with Spielberg. But, if you wanted the dark horror, you go with Crichton. I go with Crichton.

What I remember most when seeing this is that it was the first movie where digital sound was synced with the film print. And, when the Tyrannosaur shows up in the rain to attack, I know you're supposed to be terrified, but I was applauding wildly, absolutely floored by the Visual Effects!

Otherwise, this is a pretty typical Spielberg production: Flat cinematography, lots of push ins to actors' faces, precocious children that are subsequently set upon by dinosaurs, ghosts, etc., overripe acting by hammy actors, etc. I know you're supposed to want the children to be saved. I just wanted them to be eaten!

I would be much better if someone remade this as Crichton wrote it. Supposedly, Crichton had thought about directing it, but was very uncertain about handling the Visual Effects. But, since this movie is basically "Westworld" with dinosaurs, I think he could have pulled it off.

Jurassic Park starts off with a glimpse of the danger the dinosaur represents then introduces the characters and the park. The park is first showcased as potential visitors would discover it, they see the dinosaurs, then learn how they're made, before everything start to go awry.

The film plays with our fears of the unseen because in a good portion of it we don't actually see the scary dinosaurs being scary. We hear them, we know they are lurking off camera but we don't actually see them. It's such a good build up that when we see "the monsters" it's scary. My heart was racing like the little child I was when I first saw it. The suspense is one of the things that get you, even more than the few jump scares the movie has.

Watching Jurassic Park now  made me realize how smart the plot is. lt plays on concerns people would have if this park was really about to open. Some characters only have dollar signs in their eyes and others see it as something incredible that can turn deadly, which it does but it doesn't take away from the fact that it could be wonderful.

The special effects in this film look as good now as they were when the movie first came out. It thought me that even the most incredible things can be dangerous.

Based on Michael Crichton's novel of the same name and nothing short of a filmmaking masterpiece, Jurassic Park was the modern introduction for cinemagoers to the long lost prehistoric world that was brought to life with the right mixture of animatronics and CGI from the mind of critically acclaimed director Steven Spielberg, as the film is further elevated by its spectacular performances. Going on to create a cultural obsession with dinosaurs and a franchise with everything from three sequels, comic books and video games, Jurassic Park was, evidently, a hit.

Employing themes and ideas that would largely go lost on children that watched it in 1993 - or even now -, and an array of dinosaurs, Jurassic Park appeals to a wide berth of audiences, from adults right down to the children who would go on to become infatuated with the prehistoric life forms (and the merchandizing that comes with them). Utilizing a proper mix of CGI - for certain dinosaurs or situations - and animatronics, Spielberg's Jurassic Park doesn't have much to do in terms of successfully suspending disbelief at a visual level when it comes to animating the wide variety of dinosaurs.

Standing apart from their fellow dinosaurs, the T-Rex and the Velociraptors have turned into a vicious mainstay of the franchise, as they consistently wreak havoc on the humans (and other timid dinosaurs) in all three movies through an utterly unpredictable and menacing nature. Like how the allure of strong horror movies lies on both the horror and human element equally, Spielberg's Jurassic Park doesn't singularly rely on just the dinosaurs, as the humans play a role just as important as their scaly co-stars in the central narrative.

Drawing on the immense talent of the adult cast of actors - from Sam Neill to fan favourite Jeff Goldblum -, Jurassic Park captures the thematic quandaries that comes with John Hammond's park and the genetic tampering of dinosaurs, as the characters either argue or project their varied thoughts on the matter, from Alan Grant and Ellie Sattler's initial gushing over the dinosaurs to Ian Malcolm's highly realistic projection of disdain towards Hammond's idealistic, primordial nonsense, as all characters help project the spectrum of thoughts from the audience in Crichton and Koepp's terrific writing.

While much of the grimdark and violent source material by Crichton were either removed or altered to fit Spielberg's vision of having Jurassic Park appeal towards a younger audience - with screenwriter David Koepp coming on board to rework the earlier scripts were also conceived by Crichton -, the core themes of the humans playing God through science persist and translate fantastically even in this day and age where they remain as relevant as ever.

There are some elements of Jurassic Park that, watching it twenty years later, do not hold up, but the special effects are not among them. The technical achievements efficiently distract from the shortcomings of the plot and help make Jurassic Park just as thrilling and awe-inducing as it was in 1993.

1993's Jurassic Park was groundbreaking on so many levels. It features special effects that, 22 years later, have me saying, "Wow! That's incredible!" At that time, filmmaking was really reaching a pinnacle in realistic effects. Animatronics and puppetry are way more believalbe than strictly computer generated imagery. And since Hollywood went in the direction of CGI rather than the former, many films have lost their authenticity. There's a reason why the original Star Wars trilogy has fans' hearts more than the prequel trilogy--the movies feel more real. It creates a world more believable.

And with the unprecedented effects going into this movie, we really do see the height of that technology used onscreen. The genuineness exceeds that of most current sci-fi action films.

Steven Spielberg and his team create a world so realistic that we forget it doesn't exist. This is a pure adventure film and a real rush. It's anything but cliche, and the characters don't make annoying decisions trying to survive the dinosaurs.

The only thing that may be missing from this film is really solid character development. We get interesting scenarios that question certain characters' morals. But the written-in subplots in order to show depth, for the most part, feel like they're just written-in.

But we have a film that we can't really complain about. We'll sacrifice a little depth for a story and script that are so gripping that the film doesn't feel the least bit dated over 2 decades later. Now THAT is incredible!

I don't consider Jurassic Park a Spielberg classic. It doesn't have the same sense of youthful wonder his more accomplished films had like Close Encounters of The Third Kind. The scene where Richard Dreyfuss is in his car and the lights stop behind then fly away, that scene is more exhilarating than anything in Jurassic Park. Seeing the dinosaurs is cool, but the only time they really come alive for me are the death scenes -- such as Wayne Knight in the rain and mud looking for the DNA canister with a raptor toying with him. The only interesting parts of the movie are the glimpses we get of the behavior of the dinosaurs, and when we get clues to how they think. Knight's death was very enjoyable for people looking for that kind of insight. It's my favorite scene in the whole movie. 

There's not much going on besides the action and the commercial appeal of the park itself. Jeff Goldblum is the best character. He gets the movie an extra star from me because in many scenes he actually points out the flaws in the film and you realize without the flaws you wouldn't have his witty commentary. He's seems self-aware and oblivious at the same time. The kids also stand out. Too often in action movies kids are just there to scream and be in danger and be saved, but the kids here get some character development and are just as important to the story as the adults. That's a trademark of older Spielberg movies. If he wasn't making movies he'd probably be a children's entertainer. Of course, the stars of the show are the dinosaurs. They're awesome and their action scenes are intense. Unfortunately, the majesty of seeing them is forced instead of implied so it isn't as powerful as it could have been. It's an action movie, and I think Spielberg did do a pretty good job with the limited amount of time he had to marvel at the world he created.

Something of a fairy tale in the world of monster-driven CG epics, Jurassic Park is the classic that keeps on giving. The action simply cannot be missed, partially because it stretches wall-to-wall in the film; but make no mistake, Jurassic Park is a blockbuster with profound substance. For every jaw-dropping shot of a prehistoric lizard terrorizing paleontologists, there is a comment on behalf of Jeff Goldblum likening the advancements made by Jurassic Park's scientists to the tendency of more ambitious humans to assume the role of God, occasionally with dire consequences. Part thriller, part family-dynamic drama, viewing Jurassic Park should be considered a practice for coming of age for all cinematic diehards.

Essentially a perfect film, and my personal favorite of Spielberg's. The dinosaurs are brought to life flawlessly- so well that the creature effects 100% hold up today, still looking much better than many recent films (and in 4k I might add). The story is perfectly paced, setting up things flawlessly in the first half so that when shit hits the fan in the second half, you are fully invested. These are some of Spielberg's most fully realized characters, portrayed brilliantly by the cast- there is no bad performance to be found here. The writing is so smartly crafted that no second of screen time is wasted. Almost every bit of dialogue, and everything you see happen before the dinosaurs break loose- has some sort of payoff for when they mayhem begins. The T-Rex sequence could arguably be the single most impressive & terrifying blockbuster action scene ever made. This movie reminds me why I love movies so much, and never fails to thrill even though I've seen it countless times

Jurassic Park. A title that nearly everyone has heard about. They might not have watched it, they might not remember a thing about if and when they watched it. They might hate it, they might love it. But one thing is: no one can ignore it. Jurassic Park, based on the book by Michael Crichton, is simply one of the greatest films of all time. The film, a little over 21 years old at the 
time this review has been published, is not only one of Steven Speilberg's greatest works, but is also his highest grossing film. The plot seems pretty simple: a group of geneticists extract dinosaur DNA from mosquitos and create dinosaur clones. John Hammond, a billionaire entrepreneur, then creates an amusement park which allows tourists to see dinosaurs. Sounds like a great idea, right? Ian Malcom doesn't seem to think so. Malcom, along with palienotologist Dr. Alan Grant, and a few others, go to the park to get a preview of it. A lawyer accompanies them; if he deems the park dangerous, he's shutting it down. So it all goes well until Dennis Nedry, one of the park's staff, shuts down all security measures in the park, letting the dinos go loose. This serves as a distraction for him, so he can get dino embryos and sell them for over a million dollars. His plan foils; and the park is destroyed by the havoc causing dinos, who also claimed a few lives along the way. 

The movie is simply brilliant. While some may focus on hidden agendas, other simply enjoy the thriller-with-horror-elements and the dinos running amok as the tiny humans try to escape. Whatever your case may be, we can all agree that combined with the fantastic score, amazing acting and great script, as well as the breathtaking CGI and it's brilliant merging with animatronics, that the entire movie is utterly jaw dropping--a classic that we all know and love. From the scary T-Rex roaring in the warm summer night's pouring rain, to the highly intelligent velociraptors hunting down every last human, this movie is definitely a great treat for dino experts, horror cravers, thrill seekers, and even casual movie watchers.

One of the all-time great imaginative entertainments, and in its own way one of the most important movies ever.  Entirely new possibilities were opened up by its pioneering use of visual effects, and what is truly amazing is how well the effects have held up; there is nothing that seems to have aged at all, even as effects have become more advanced by the year.  It is impossible to overstate the impact this movie had on the public when it was first released; it was as if something only seen on Star Trek had burst into reality. And It isn't just the effects. This movie is wonderfully constructed. The well-conceived plot unfolds at an ideal pace, with anticipatory tension, and scenes which are kinetic and scary.  

Jurassic Park is a film rich with classic Sci-fi themes, centering on reckless overreach in search of a grand, elusive goal. It isn't a movie about hubris, though hubris is certainly involved.  It is really about the allure of a personal dream, an allure that can be impossible to resist, but also impossible to fully realize in a way one can control. It is interesting that a film about the damage wreaked by a relentless attempt to realize one's imagination is itself a complete fulfillment of imagination.

The acting is well-suited for the film.  Sam Neill is a particular favorite of mine; There are few actors who I have more fond childhood associations with.  I'm also a fan of Jeff Goldblum, who is always a welcome presence, as is Laura Dern and the late Sir Richard Attenborough, who as the Park's creator conveys the almost childlike wonder which drives his foolhardy quest to re-enchant the world.  Perhaps this is part of the resonance of this particular film.  I find myself far more sympathetic towards John Hammond than one would assume I should be.  in today's world, we are fixated on innovation but have little room for wonder.  Among people of letters, the dominant goal is deconstruction, and there is a sense that nothing in human experience can be enchanted anymore, because we've taken everything apart.  This is likely illusory, but it and similar experiences had become pervasive in the collective mindset by the 90's, and remain so.  There is something so pure and wonderful about the passion that drives Mr Hammond, as foolish and destructive as it ends up becoming.  All he wants is to share his unsullied sense of wonder with the world.  His failure is in the necessity to exercise a level of control that no human can possess.  It doesn't really matter that the science described in the film isn't actually possible (due to DNA's relatively short shelf life).  The immutable truth here regards the limits of our ability to control nature.  Its a Tolkienish lesson, that our desires aren't the problem, it is having means at our disposal that exceed our natural limitations, because those limitations are a big part of who we are.  They must be recognized and accepted to be sane.  Yet it is in our nature to continue to open up Pandora's Box and be engulfed once again in unforeseen chaos, ever the result of both our natural curiosity, and our futile attempt to control and change the natural order.  

But is it a lovely dream.  At the end of the movie, as the airplane flies away from the island, with that wondrous soundtrack in the background (one of my favorite musical scores ever), the face of the mad dreamer John Hammond tells it all: his sadness at the catastrophe he has engineered is there, but we also can tell he'll always treasure that dream and never let it go. We'll never be able to bring back dinosaurs in actuality, nor should we try.  But we should treasure a movie which is so imbued with wonderment and imagination, and one which nurtured these qualities in the public, something that is more revolutionary than even its visual wizardry.

If you didn't know already Jurassic Park was based on the book written by Micheal Crichton.  David Koepp and Micheal Crichton were in charge of putting the screenplay together which would explain why it followed the book so well.  If you haven't read the book I suggest you do because it is an amazing book, now back to the movie.  In this movie during a preview tour, the park suffers a major power breakdown during a bad storm that allows all of the dinosaur to break free of their exhibits and run free.

On the island of Isla Nublar, a new park has just been built with genetically engineered dinosaurs. They are transporting in some of those dinosaurs when one of the workers is killed by a velociraptor. The founder of the park, John Hammond, (Richard Attenborough) is forced to get an inspection of the park due to this incident and he requests Paleontologist Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neill) and his assistant, Dr. Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern) to come to the park and ensure that it is safe. Hammond's lawyer Donald Gennaro (Martin Ferrero) is also joining them because he is the one that is requiring the inspection and he brought a chaos theorist Dr. Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum).  After a long bumpy helicopter ride they get to the island and they are amazed to discover that Hammond has actually created living dinosaurs.  Even though amazed everyone but the lawyer have their doubts. Later, Hammond's grandchildren Lex and Tim (Ariana Richards and Joseph Mazzello) join the group to take a tour of the park. While on the tour the come in contact of an ill triceratops and Sattler leaves the tour to take care of her.  Dennis Nedry (Wayne Knight) who wishes to steal embryos from the park to sell to a secret buyer sets up a program that shuts off all the power to the park except the velociraptors paddock. Due to this selfish act, many dinosaurs escape their paddocks, including the deadly Tyrannosaurus Rex, who, during a thunderstorm, escapes his paddock and attacks the cars on the tour. Malcolm is injured & Grant and the children are then lost in the park. Meanwhile, Hammond, Sattler and the rest of the operations team learn that Nedry has locked up the computer system to cover his tracks. They attempt to get power back in the park in order to escape the island. After shutting down the system, then restoring it, they then realize they just shut the power off to the velociraptors paddock and now they are also on the loose, & are now on the hunt for the visitors.

This movie won 3 oscars which is amazing, one of them for Best Effects, Visual Effects,  which you have to give credit to Dennis Muren, Phil Tippett, Michael Lantieri, and Stan Winston.  The CGI in this movie was amazing,  The dinosaurs looked real.  You can not tell that they are computer generated, I almost felt that I was at a real park with real animals.  Well Done.

This movie gets an A+!  I have always enjoyed movies that director Steven Spielburg has put together and he doesn't fail to deliver on this one.  The actors really make you feel like the dinosaurs are there and the story has a nice mix of action and humor with even a bit of suspense.  This is one of my top ten favorite movies and if you haven't seen it yet go get it and watch it.

Jurassic Park is a showcase for how masterful Steven Spielberg is at stirring suspense, awe and terror. Your hairs will stand on your skin, your eyes widened, jaw agape, teeth grit and legs tapping at the building atmosphere. If you thought Jaws was suspenseful, imagine it tens times more so, now in 3D, remastered for further viewing pleasure. We all know the story; a team of researchers is trapped on a Dinosaur ridden island after communications are knocked out. This unforgettable classic blockbuster hasn't aged a bit.

Steven Spielberg's sweeping style and ability to pass awe onto the viewer remains unbeatable, within the first five minutes you are fixated on the cage that is being hauled into storage, as workers risk their lives shipping the precious yet dangerous cargo inside. What I love most is the facial expressions the actors pull throughout. Richard Attenborough gleams with happiness and proudness, leaving Laura Dern and Sam Neill looking onwards with bewilderment as if they're about to have a breakdown. Things really get going when the Dinosaurs break loose, watching the camera close up to the actors as they turn around in horror looking upon the might of these monsters gets you pumped. The acting is utterly convincing and I love the cast, it would be great if they were to reunite for Jurassic World, but I'm cool with Chris Pratt, Ty Simpkins and Bryce Dallas Howard taking the leads.

Some things don't age over time. Sigourney Weaver remains as attractive as ever since her Alien days, and is as talented as ever, and the same can be said for the special effects in this masterpiece. It's fantastic, sometimes you expect to laugh at how bad some films have aged, I laugh at the original Total Recall as sad as it is to say it's not aged well at all with the dated visuals and animatronics, yet Jurassic Park looks astounding and sounds powerful, hearing that Tyrannosaurus roar over and over again is staggering and harrowing, not to mention epic! And in 3D this thrilling adventure looks wonderful, you can peer into the screen as the depth has enhanced the island and its inhabitants. 

If you can get your hands on a 3D release do it, simply put worth every penny and to see this classic given an update is pleasing. Let's see what is given a 3D update next: Maybe Twister/Aliens/Speed, who knows, but for now Jurassic Park is even more powerful than ever.

"PREHISTORIC THEME PARK"

- 'Jurassic Park' is a 1993 adventure film directed by Steven Spielberg (Jaws, E. T.) and based on the novel by Michael Crichton. This movie forms the first installment of the popular dinosaur film franchise with the same name. It's my favorite movie, due because it was the first one I saw in the theatres and it has everything a movie needs. What kid doesn't like dinosaurs?  I really love the story, although a lot of drastic changes have been made in comparison to the novel, and the effects and sounds are absolutely amazing. Undeniable, this is the film I have seen the most, and even now I still spot little details that feel like I never saw before. 'Jurassic Park' is the greatest film ever made and won three Academy Awards. It was an absolute blockbuster and had a whole merchandise around it. I also would like to praise John Williams the fantastic soundtrack, and of course the cast of 'Jurassic Park': starring Sam Neil (Dead Calm, The Tudors), Laura Dern (October Sky, I Am Sam), sir Richard Attenborough (The Great Escape, Miracle on 34th Street), Jeff Goldblum (The Fly, Independence Day), Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction, Star Wars prequels), Ariana Richards (Tremors, Battledogs) , Joseph Mazzello (The River Wild, The Hollow), Wayne Knight (Space Jam, Rat Race), Bob Peck  (Edge of Darkness, Lord of the Flies) and Martin Ferraro (Oscar, Stop or My Mom Will Shoot). "Welcome to Jurassic Park."

Paleontologist Alan Grant (Neil) and his girlfriend paleobotanist Ellen Sattler (Dern) are invited by the eccentric millionaire John Hammond (Attenborough) to visit his theme park on an island near Costa Rica and give their honest opinion. In the helicopter they meet lawyer Donald Gennaro (Ferraro), who represents the park's investors, and his guest mathematician Ian Malcolm (Goldblum). Shortly after their arrival, the group is stunned to see a living Brachiosaurus. Hammond's scientists have succeeded in cloning extinct dinosaurs, that are now ready to be shown in 'Jurassic Park'. 

The group is joined by Hammond's grandchildren Lex (Richards) and Tim (Mazzello) for a tour in the park. While the guests take place in the automatically controlled vehicles, John goes to the control room to follow the ride. Unfortunately, several of the dinosaurs fail to appear. When the cars are near the triceratops area, the group steps out and stumble upon the park's veterinary who is treating an ill triceratops. Ellie offers him to help examine the creature and stays behind, as the others continue the tour. When a storm is approaching the island, most of the employers are going home for the weekend, only chief engineer Ray Arnold (Jackson), the park's game warden Robert Muldoon (Peck) and computer programmer Dennis Nedry (Knight) are staying.  When Nedry, who has been hired by the corporal rival to steal embryos, deactivates the security system, all hell is about to break lose. The cars with the guests have stopped in front of the Tyrannosaurus Rex paddock. With no electrical fences to stop her, the prehistoric animal attacks...

Impressive animatronics don't save this predictable and overrated film which is complete with stock characters, a weak plot, failed attempts at suspense and laughable dialogue.  If this film were put in the hands of someone who could think outside the box then I think it could be very cool, but in the hands of the cookie-cutter, money-hungry Spielberg it is truly a lame piece of garbage that offers no surprises other than the fact that there are dinosaurs (which isn't really much of a surprise after the first one you see).  Every character has their story cut out for them as soon as the film begins, which includes but is not limited to: the "greedy corporate sellout", the "young girl with not-so-hidden talents", the "reluctant but good-hearted protagonist", the "wise-cracking mathematician who has no reason to exist" and well...pretty much everyone else.  This movie is terrible.  I would rather re-watch the 3rd one.   At least that one utilized the presence of dinosaurs to some sort of cool effect.  This movie couldn't even kill any of it's characters (besides the snooty lawyer who you can tell will die as soon as he's presented).  What a piece of shit.

 Jurassic Park is basically Jaws with dinosaurs and it pales in comparison with the latter. Because Jaws couldn't show the shark for most of the first half of the movie, the film is forced to focus on building its three main characters, Brody, Hooper and Quint. Also because the earlier film focuses so clearly on only three vivid characters, they are much better defined than anyone on the much larger cast of Jurassic Park.  There is not a lot of depth to the characters. Most of them are more caricatures than characters.

My sole complaint was that some of the characterization gets lost in the second hour. I still feel that way a little bit, yet two decades have helped me see that it really doesn't matter. Jurassic Park is full throttle entertainment, plain and simple

 

Now, as much as I recognize this film's faults, that doesn't mean I don't enjoy it. As a special effects thrill ride, Jurassic Park succeeds.

Jurassic Park doesn't hold up against the test of time. Looking back at the plot you realize there barely is one. The movie establishes a good premise early on, but it doesn't succeed in exploring the possibilities that come along with it. The movie is really just a vehicle for the idea behind it instead of having a plot that succeeds in reaching all opportunities that the premise allows. A great example of a movie that does this is The Truman Show. It was very original from the start and had a plot that helped its premise stretch its legs. Jurassic Park's creators' only objective was to make money off of the world they set up around the movie. Second after that in their mind was to make a good movie. Hey, at least the special effects were good (for the time).

Steven Spielberg hits gold with this film that focuses on the cloning of dinosaurs and a themed park on a tropical island. Based on the Michael Crichton book, the film follows two dinosaur experts and a chaos theorist who are invited to view a dinosaur themed island by an eccentric millionaire. Most of the film takes place on the island, with Spielberg wonderfully building suspense slowly and than when the big stuff happens it never disappoints. The dinosaurs don't really remind of you big special effects, but more as real dinosaurs who wonderfully add to the film and are the best part. Whenever watching the film, you are amazed by the sense of detail and authenticity that is brought to each dinosaur. The cast is also perfect, primarily Sam Neill, Laura Dern and Jeff Goldblum, while Richard Attenborough gives a terrific supporting performance as the millionaire. The action is terrific, John Williams's score is memorable and the film never disappoints. Once again, Spielberg has delivered another winner. Well done.

Steven Spielberg has brings us to a world we have never seen before like Jurassic Park and boy its wonderful to look at this amazing world after 20 years. This was intense yet very good. Oh my god they were outstanding and they sure still hold up after all these years and look better than a lot of films that uses CGI. My god. You need to find the time to go into this amazing world that you want to back for more.

I am actually surprised myself that i'm giving such a famous film a low score. However when I watched this film I noticed something that almost destroys this film: the characters/actors.

I think every character is one dimensional. While the mad scientist and douchebag hipster are fun, there is no feeling of development or reality.

That is why the Dinosaurs are so important. Not only is this CGI still nice to look at while not overwhelming the audience (like how films today need 20 explosions and brown filtering) but the horror and drama that the dinosaurs bring is scary. Yes the two main characters and kids are going to be ok: cause no director would DARE be that audacious- but the other characters have random fates and so it's interesting how they get whacked. The best part of some scenes is that the Dinosaurs may take a few minutes before attacking, dragging out the drama to make memorable scenes. I wish they had more hostile dinos because outside of the Trex and raptors there wasn't much else.

Overall this film is still good to watch, but only for the Dinos. Most of the humans are completely forgettable, and since they make up most of the film anyways it is this film's biggest weakness.

Don't get me wrong; those special effects are absolutely jaw dropping. Miles ahead of many films that come out now, Phil Tippett's work shines as one of few bright points in this revolutionary disappointment.
The acting on all fronts leaves much to be desired, with even pros like Jeff Goldblum  and Sam Neill delivering underwhelming performances (the predictably trashy show by Wayne Night doesn't help either), and Spielberg's usually masterful direction lacks the sense of awe that should come with a land of dinosaurs. This, combined with standard dialogue and trope characters, made Jurassic Park a remarkably forgettable experience for me. I really wish I knew what I was missing.

Everything about Jurassic Park impressed me. The cast is fantastic and the story superb. In the first half we get to gaze in wonder at the breathtaking CGI dinosaurs, and the second half we watch in fear as the dinosaurs run amok. After 20 years, the effects in this film are as impressive, if not better than what we have today.  The characters are all memorable in their own ways, and the score by John Williams is near perfect. It's brilliantly made and provides numerous thrills around every corner. Jurassic Park gets 5/5 stars (A+).

This is movie is awesome in every sense of the word. It captured dinosaurs on film like no other. It didn't rely solely on special effects, thankfully. I mean the climbing up the electric fence scene and the raptors in the kitchen scene are damn near perfect. If those scenes don't get your eyes glued to the screen, then I don't know what will. The music is great too. It's awe inspiring and it makes your hair stand on end. The characters in this movie feel suitably real as well. They all act like real people. Nobody felt like a fake movie character, which was rather nice. This movie also has possibly my favorite child performances of all time. Both of the kids are fantastic. When dinosaurs are coming for them, they look absolutely terrified. They made me believe there were actual dinosaurs chasing them. This film is a classic and I cannot recommend it enough.

Even twenty years later those T-Rex effects hold up pretty damn well. Which shows the power of a top notch director like Spielberg, who can film the fantastic, using revolutionary technology, and there is barely a moment where you don't believe what you are seeing on the screen. Compare that with the effects-heavy films of today, where everything is so digitally altered, you barely know what's real anymore.
This is a brilliant film and in my mind will always be regarded as a classic.

Groundbreaking even to this day, Jurassic Park changed the way we look at visual effects forever, with amazing CGI, masterful animatronics, memorable performances and contextually crafted terror. This Spielberg masterpiece will be remembered for years to come.

While logic-wise, this film is certainly with its flaws, the spectacle elements and general power to thrill (sometimes even scare) is just as awesome today, as it was back in 1993.  Just as Steven Spielberg invented the summer blockbuster with 'Jaws', so with this he reinvented it.  The structuring is perfect in its blending of scientific exposition and heart-thudding suspense, it somehow retains the ability to inspire an adult audience whilst remaining more-or-less family-friendly, and its ground-breaking technological aspects are still arguably unrivalled by any other.  In this case, the smaller faults are entirely overshadowed by the grander picture.

This review is for the 3D version, of "Jurassic Park". Frankly I love 3D, but , it did little for the movie, there are SO MANY flaws and continuity errors in this movie and they are ALL still there, in spite of the 3D makeover. We all know how the T-Rex steps out from behind the fence, yet later that spot is a drop-off, it must be a sink hole, but did you ever notice how when the T-Rex smashes through the SUV roof, the plexiglass breaks in half, but of course, in the close-up, it is a magically restored, whole piece and perfect shield, protecting the kids? Now I did still enjoy the movie and carefully took in all the 3D atmosphere, but some of the conversion was NOT translated properly. Mainly regarding the people. The shoulder that faced away from the camera did NOT seem the proportionate distance away, causing the actors to appear strangely hunched over, like something looks wrong, but one cannot quite figure out what is. Overall, I liked the 3D transfer, but, it was MORE of a spectacle just to see "Jurassic Park" on the big screen.

The richest 10% own 85% of the world's assets. True story. 
Elysium seeks to explore this dichotomy between the haves and have nots in a dystopia some century hence.
The film is beautifully rendered (especially in IMAX) with the same grungy feel employed by 33 year old director Neill Blomkamp in his debut sensation District 9. On earth that is. 
In  Elysium, a paradise disc spinning tantalising above earth, everything is clean, green and bright. So everyone wants to get there, but only the richest can.
Blomkamp explores the same theme (segregation) as he does in his first movie and makes excellent use again of Sharlto Copley as a rivetingly psychotic South African rogue agent.  
The pacing is brisk, the action breathless and nonstop, the plot engaging and the scenery and tech never less than involving. 
HOWEVER.
The film is too sweary. The F-bomb is dropped more times than actual bombs, and that is saying something. The violence is a bit much, too. 
Damon is too worthy. In 30 Rock and his comic rivalry with Jimmy Kimmel, Matt has proved himself to be a cheeky funny guy. He has some witty altercations with droids, sticking it to the man at the price of a broken arm, but as his radiation sickness ramps up and his exosuit clamps on, the wit dries up. He ends up being a little flat and much less impressive than in, say, The Talented Mr Ripley or Bourne,
Jodie Foster is absolutely rubbish. This is, as others have said, a career low. She spends the whole film trying and failing to master an English accent, which evidently wasn't enough as it had to be overdubbed. Her ice-queen villain shtick would have been much better executed by Sigourney Weaver or Glenn Close or Meryl Streep or Tilda Swinton. She knocks off half a star single-handedly. 
The script is too heavy-handed after a chirpy start. The characters aren't quite developed enough and take second place to the action, which is always a mistake, especially in a movie which evidently has designs to be more than just a shoot-em-up. The main love interest plus sick kid could have been moving but is just a bit meh. The soundtrack sounded too much like Prometheus or the Dark Knight with all the blaring low horns. The implausibilities were a little hard to stomach in places. 
All in all, however, it is a watchable, engaging film that raises some critical questions about how we in the film-watching West are going to actually *do* something to make a fairer future for everybody, not just we lucky few.

Great effects for its time, and Spielberg knows how to do this kind of film. However, the script was not particularly good, and it's areal shame. Let me get this straight: a man discovers a way of recreating fucking dinosaurs, and his idea of putting this to good use is to charge tickets to a dino zoo? With a couple of jeeps driving a handful of people around? Who'd let him have that zoo? In 24 hours the USA would invade, apprehend the entire scientific staff and move the dinosaurs to Guantanamo base. And then you have the incredible safety measures: the dinosaurs are kept at bay by an electric fence. One kind of obvious problem: what if the power goes down? And then you have these goofy characters doing goofy things. I can forgive any amount of goofiness if the characters are lovable; I LOVE Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom. But there is no Indiana Jones here, just some idiots who deliberately try to get themselves killed most of the time. The film needed a rewrite. Badly.

Jurassic Park is one of the best movies of the 1990's and one of Steven Spielberg's best movies. Everything about this movie is flawless. I absolutely love the story to this movie. It is based off the book by Michael Crichton, but I have never read the book. Dinosaurs being reborn by Frog DNA and Dinosaur blood in Mosquitos covered in sap is one of the coolest ideas for a story ever. All of the characters are well developed and very enjoyable. Sam Neil, Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, and Richard Attenborough are fantastic in the movie. The Dinosaur effects are amazing. When you see parts of a dinosaur, it is animatronic. When you see a full dinosaur, it is CGI. Spielberg was careful not to use too much CGI though. It also takes a lot of time to see the dinosaurs. If this movie was made today, they would show the dinosaurs right away. I recently saw this movie on the big screen in post conversion 3D. The 3D is absolutely fantastic for this film and it has the best post converted 3D I have ever seen (I have not seen Titanic in 3D). Overall, this is a masterpiece of film. It has great characters, a great story, outstanding special effects, and great pacing. Jurassic Park is one of my favorite movies of all time.

The special effects are handled with the utmost care and stand the test of time even with CGI technology at it's infancy for the time.  The attacks are frightening without being needlessly gory.  The action is on-the-edge-of-your-seat stuff.  The philosophical questions and issues raised are intriguing.  The way in which the dino's are brought to life is taken with care to make it believable.  The first time we see the dinosaurs are breathtaking.

This film has great pacing.  It teases the prehistoric animals through much of the first third so it builds anticipation for the viewer instead of chucking lots of dino's in left right and centre.

Now admittedly there are some things I didn't like.  Brattyness or stupidity of kids are always irritating in films.  Much to my delight it never drove me to the point of wanting the dino's to eat any of the children.  Just about.  The way of which Dino's are brought back to life but then breed, and wreck havoc is a good spin on things but I didn't buy how the scientists nor park warden's didn't figure that out.  Still, I brush those things under the carpet of movie magic.  Still thoroughly enjoyable and worthy of better sequels than it had.  Works better as a stand alone film.

When I first saw Jurassic Park 20 years ago, it was truly remarkable. I'd seen animation blended with live action before, but always in a more cartoony way (like Mary Poppins.) Now we had computers inserting dinosaurs that looked so genuine they blended right into the action. The story was exciting, and kept the audience on the edge of their seats. The acting was solid, and the annoying kids were tolerable because they provided some laughs. I was even willing to overlook all the glaring goofs that the movie-makers failed to edit out. This movie was one of the first that made me see a future (which we now live in) where anything a director can imagine is possible to manufacture in a computer. But time has passed. As I mentioned we live in the future now. So modern minds decide it is time to give this classic new life by transforming it into a 3-D experience.

The 3-D transformation was really surprising. It amazed me how much effort they clearly put into this adaptation, because it almost felt like the movie was originally filmed with 3-D cameras. They achieved depth so masterfully, that it didn't seem out of place or tacked on. However, there is one problem, and that is the fact that Spielberg never filmed this movie intending for it to expand into 3 dimensions. You can tell this because there were an over-abundance of close-ups where people were talking, and the 3-D effect is useless in moments like this. No one wants to see Richard Attenborough's nose hairs in eye-popping 3-D. Likewise, the dinosaurs rarely attack the screen, so you don't get that moment which makes the audience jump because it appears the jaws are coming right at them. So, while the 3-D is integrated so seamlessly, it still feels tacked on. I appreciate the experience of seeing Jurassic Park in a new format, but it didn't seem necessary.

Seeing the film in IMAX was my biggest mistake. This was beyond what even the most skilled computer tech could make work for a movie that was filmed in a standard aspect ratio. I did appreciate the size of things that were supposed to be enormous on screen. For instance, when the jeeps enter the park and we're shown the gates as they pass overhead, I found myself actually looking up at them as if I was going through them. The problem is most shots are not intended to look so massive, so we frequently noticed awkward stretching. The legs of characters looked strangely long and spindly. The greatest downfall of combining both 3-D and this extreme size was that it brought the CGI into so much detail. Suddenly I wasn't amazed like I was 20 years ago, instead I found myself thinking "this could be so much better if it was made today." You see, where 20 years ago I often failed to see where CGI stopped and live-action started, now it was being thrust in my face to make it clear what was real. In the end, the story was still intact and that's a winner, but perhaps they should have just left well enough alone and avoided changing a landmark film like this one.

On its 20th anniversay in 2013, watching Jurassic Park on IMAX 3D is a nostalgic joy. To experience once again the awe of seeing the dinosaurs come alive on the big screen. The big sounds echoing the thunderous footsteps of the mighty T-Rex. The suspense of the raptor hunt. It all remains here. 3D has made the dinosaurs more realistic, but the film was cut with many close up of actor and that is a little disrupting on such a huge screen. And the film footage is showing its age now that we are so accustomed to digital projections. Cinema halls of old are mostly gone, and IMAX is the only modern venue to experience Jurassic Park as I experienced in 1993, with the awe and fright of a child.

An overrated flick that simply was nothing more than just a display of what were at time "mind-blowing" special effects. The special effects are the only real special part of the film, which were revolutionary at the time and still hold up very well even by today's standards. But like many other visually spectacular films, what's really the point of expensive effects when they're accompanied by a merely okay film?
For the 2 hrs duration, Jurassic Park IMAX 3D interminably amazes me for its originality and classic thrills that transcends through time.

In Spielberg's legendary blockbuster classic, Dr's Alan Grant (Sam Neill) and Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern) are called by millionaire John Hammond (Richard Attenborough) to preview his new amusement park, called Jurassic Park, which features real-life, cloned dinosaurs taken from the DNA of pre-historic mosquitoes. Joining them is mathematician Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum) and Hammond's two grandchildren, played by Joseph Mazzelo and Ariana Richards. When a smuggling employee (Wayne Knight) shuts down the system and steals some dinosaur embryos, the dinos go mad and Jurassic Park turns from a park of wonder to a park of total nightmare.

Before I make any criticisms about this film, I must say that the visual effects for the dinosaurs are some of the best CGI effects I've ever seen. After 20 years, the dinos still look extremely menacing, and I applaud Spielberg and his crew for a magnificent job at creating such magnificent creatures.

As for the terror shown in the film, Spielberg uses the fear he spreads in Jaws and carries it on in this film. Many of the frightening sequences in this film are not only thrilling, but also fun and entertaining, such as the first encounter with the T-Rex.

For the most part, I enjoyed the cast in this film. Sam Neill and Laura Dern had a fine chemistry, and Attenborough was enjoyable. Samuel L. Jackson stole the show as Jurassic Park employee Arnold, who says the best line in the film, "Hold on to your butts." But Jeff Goldblum really stole the show in this film. His lines are clever and had the most entertaining character in the film.

Having said that, Jurassic Park lacks a strong character development. The film never explained why someone would want to re-create dinosaurs, and the romance between Neill and Dern was never developed. Wayne Knight's character is never fully put to use, cause it is not explained why he would want to smuggle the cloned dino medicine.

My biggest problem are the two kids. They are extremely annoying. Not only are they stupid, but the situations they get into don't make any sense. For instance, the boy gets electrocuted while climbing down a 10,000 volt electric fence, and he still survived. How does that happen? If I had it my way, then I would have the T-Rex eat the kids, then Jurassic Park would have been a much better film. But my belief is that Spielberg is a family man and he didn't want to disturb the little ones. Oh well, but at least they're not as annoying as Jar Jar Binks.

Despite my small problems for this film, I view Jurassic Park as a revolutionary landmark in film and a Spielberg classic. While not his best film, it's still a fun ride.

Although the concepts and general framework of this story are faithfully lifted from the Crichton-penned source material, in action it's got Steven Spielberg's fingerprints all over it. That isn't a negative, really, as the director was still clearly in his prime, but it does fit quite snugly next to the other family-friendly adventure flicks in his portfolio in that it's big and intense without going so far over-the-top as to scare the kiddos. Of course, at the time the real star here was the film's fantastic effects work - it was CGI's coming out party, after all - and that aspect has aged surprisingly well over the past two decades. Sure, if we look closely a few seams might show here or there, but the raptors remain unsettlingly vivid and our first glimpses of a grazing brachiosaurus remain nothing short of stunning. Some excellent casting decisions enrich the whole package (Jeff Goldblum is pitch-perfect as the muttering, brainy Ian Malcolm) and there are plenty of character moments scattered about to flesh out the more extravagant action sets.

Jurassic Park. An island full of dinosaurs who terrorize people; a simple premise but extremely well done. From beginning to end this film is just an enjoyable watch. Back in 1993 when it was released these never-before-seen effects had to have wowed audiences, and even now it still holds up with the anamatronics, CGI combo, it is really good; I've seen worst stuff in other movies and TV series. The characters I thought were pretty well done and acted, you really didn't want certain things happen to certain people and I really like Sam Neil as Alan Grant. Now, I was really exited to watch my favorite film on the big screen and especially in 3D, I watched it in IMAX as well, something I had never done before, and boy did it deliver. The 3D in this movie was one of the best I've seen in ages, better than Man of Steel and Iron Man 3 by far. Jurassic Park in the third dimension brought a whole new life too it, just some of the scenes with the trees, and leaves and then an awesome scene in the kitchen was good in 3D. So yes, I think Jurassic Park will continue being my favored film for a long time to come; I do enjoy the sequels too but this will always be... AWESOMENESS.

Out of all the current movies in theaters, I chose to see Jurassic Park the other day, a remastered 3D rerelease. I believe I made a very good choice. Jurassic Park features an excellent buildup, use of foreshadowing, and cinematic tension. The movie may be less than subtle at times and occasionally feel as if it's trying a little to hard to be like, "wow!", but it is a classic 'Movie Magic' experience and does inspire a sense of wonder and transportation in the audience. The cast puts on mostly heartfelt roles, the attention to detail is commendable, and it's plain fun. The movie's falling side of climax felt rushed, cut short, and as an afterthought, but its missteps are more than forgivable in the big picture. It's easy to remember why Steven Spielberg is the most commercially successful director.

Jurassic Park remains the gold standard now twenty years after it's release, and for good reason: it's an undeniably fun romp through a childhood science fiction dream come to life. Equal parts humor and suspense, the film is pure thrills from start to finish. What most stands out, though, is how realistic the special effects and animatronics are in Jurassic Park. For my money, they look infinitely more believable (and, in turn, frightening) than anything I've seen in the twenty years since. A must-see.
