How many 3D rereleases have we seen in the last year?  As far as live-action goes, we have the disparaged (if misunderstood) 'Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace' and the criminally overrated (and tragically featuring an audio nightmare by a terrible Canadian) 'Titanic'.  Now comes a re-release of 'Jurassic Park' - the movie that not only revolutionized movie making, but also gave cinema goers a sense of old-school awe in a way that director Steven Spielberg had come to be known for.  Not only is this 3D re-release a well-done effort from the company that post-converted 'The Avengers', but it's also just a joy to see this film on the big screen - especially in IMAX 3D.  
When a wealthy entrepreneur named John Hammond (Richard Attenborough) seeks out the advice of some renowned paleontologists, Dr. Alan Grant (Sam Neill) and Ellie Sattler (Laura Dern), the doctors get more than they bargained for.  Turns out, Hammond has created an island paradise filled with cloned dinosaurs and yearns for the doctors' approval of the park.  Together with a mathematician, Ian Malcolm (Jeff Goldblum), and Hammond's grandchildren (Joseph Mazzello and Ariana Richards), the doctors set out on a tour of the park.  But, after an initial sense of wonder sets in after an encounter with a triceratops, Murphy's Law begins to take effect.  Soon the dinosaurs are loose, and the visitors on the run.  Can mankind's dream of seeing these prehistoric creatures still come to fruition, or will nature be too much for man to handle?
Say what you will about the plot and the scientific intricacies of the film, but the tyrannosaur escape alone is worth the price of admission.  In IMAX 3D, it is so real.  In two dimensions, it was terrifying and captivating enough, but add the extra dimension and incredible sound on a massive screen, and you're in for a thrilling, nostalgic movie-going experience.  The brilliant use of the then-new computer effects meshed perfectly with Stan Winston's incredible practical effect creatures is still mind-numbing and jaw-dropping today as it was two decades ago.  And if that weren't enough, the raptors in the kitchen are just as terrifying today for adults who saw the movie as kids and had the stealthy reptiles haunt their dreams.  (Oh, and if some kids saw the clip in IMAX 3D when their parents took them to see 'Oz the Great and Powerful', it'll likely scare them into insomnia as well.)  The film didn't have to have a fool-proof plot or one devoid of plot holes.  The film was the first of its kind with ground-breaking effects that made the extinct come to life and was shared with the world.  
Okay, so the film has some holes in the plot.  First, there's the perpetuated theory propped up by paleontologists in the film, but that's a topic for an article that's not a movie review.  There are other plot holes and fuzzy math and science to boot that were much better explained in the novel by Michael Crichton (who also wrote the screenplay).  However, with the sense of wonder, those issues are easily looked over.  Also, the other aspects of the film are nearly flawless.  The actors bring their characters to life with pizazz.  Neill and Dern make for a believable pair, and Goldblum is characteristically comical.  With side characters played by Samuel L. Jackson and Wayne Knight, the casting was pretty dead-on.  But no one exemplifies the solid casting decisions of the filmmakers than that of Attenborough.  The man becomes Hammond, and is the anchor of the film (even though very few wealthy entrepreneurs could likely read a blueprint). Also, the camera work by Dean Cudney was one of the best aspects of the film outside the creatures.  Add John Williams' wonderful score to the mix, and the film is complete.
There are few auteurs that could have made this film, and Spielberg was the right choice to usher in this era of computer generated effects.  This movie was a perfect showcase for the technology.  Twenty years ago it was astounding.  Seeing it again in the twenty-first century is as enjoyable as it was back then.  In fact, this film has stood the test of time so well, that even modern films struggle to achieve a level of craftsmanship that this film set the bar for.  Cinema junkies will love to see this film for the nostalgia factor, but regular folks can enjoy the film as well for the masterpiece of filmmaking that it is.  It's not advisable to turn adolescents loose to see this film, unless you enjoy striking fear into the hearts of children.  But for those old enough to understand the difference between fact and fiction, this will be a wonder to see in its 3D glory.  It's not perfect, but it's a thrilling time at the movies - again.

Only Steven Spielberg can make audiences fall in love with dinosaurs, and then make them the most terrifying creatures on earth all in the same movie. Jurassic Park is one of the best movies ever made, and it is one of Spielberg's best.

Holding up entertainingly well on its platinum anniversary, Jurassic Park presents as exciting a joyride as ever...especially in three dimensions. When it premiered, this reviewer remembers that people who saw this popcorn extravaganza first in the theater loved it and those who saw it on video...well, not AS much. Here, on the big screen and the best example of 3D post conversion yet, Spielberg spells out his formula for H'Wood success for the umpteenth time: Scares. Smarts. SFX. This CGI pioneer truly looks more authentic than most of the Dino droppings being released today.

For those born after the Clinton administration, this 20th anniversary 3D conversion of the PG-13-rated adventure centers around a multimillionaire (Sir Richard Attenborough) who unveils a new theme park featuring dinosaurs cloned using advanced DNA technology, only visitors end up fighting for their survival. 

True, the movie displays some telltale Spielbergian tics (close-ups of characters in awe, monsters playing peekaboo, a swooning John Williams score). Of course, this is one of the movies that made them iconic. Neil, Dern, Jeff Goldblum, and Attenborough shine, but the true stars are the so-real-it's-frightening dinosaurs.

Bottom line: Monster Smash.
